title: car usage appears increase london borough low traffic neighbourhoods
story: The number of motorists applying for parking permits increased massively after a council introduced five low traffic neighbourhoods meant to encourage people to end their reliance on cars.A total of 46,125 motorists applied for parking permits in the London borough of Lambeth in 2020, an 18.6 per cent increase on the previous year, when 38,901 applications were submitted.The spike coincided with the introduction of five controversial low traffic neighbourhoods (LTNs) in the borough.The figures, obtained through a Freedom of Information request, show that in Streatham Hill, where one LTN was introduced, the number of car parking permit applications nearly doubled from 1,281 in 2019 to 2,467 last year.Lambeth’s apparent increase in car use is in stark contrast to London and the country as a whole, where car ownership has declined slightly.At the height of the pandemic last year, Grant Shapps, the Transport Secretary, offered councils hundreds of millions of pounds to introduce LTNs to create a so-called “green transport revolution”.But the schemes have ided communities amid claims many have been badly designed and simply shift congestion and pollution to other roads.Campaigners, who claim Lambeth’s LTNs have forced traffic from affluent neighbourhoods onto main roads where poorer communities live, said the data shows the schemes have failed to encourage a “modal shift” away from cars to walking and cycling.Nineteen of the borough’s 21 wards saw an increase in applications for parking permits. Only Streatham South saw a decrease from 16 to 13 applications, with Knight’s Hill remaining unchanged at 11 permits for both 2019 and 2020.In 2020, 43,090 permits were actually issued by the council, an 11.9 per cent increase on 2019, when 38,510 were distributed to residents and businesses. Annual parking permits cost between £38 and £324.50 in Lambeth.A spokeswoman for One Lambeth, which is opposed to the LTNs, said: The premise of LTNs, as stated by both Lambeth Council and the Department for Transport, was to encourage a 'modal shift' away from cars to walking and cycling.“This data proves the schemes do no such thing, instead in Lambeth it has increased the numbers of cars. Worse still, it means the borough is going in the opposite direction to the rest of London and the country where car use over the same period is in decline.“The council, encouraged by Grant Shapps, has been rolling out LTNs under the auspices of a 'climate emergency' claiming that the reduction in pandemic traffic was a means to encourage people out of their cars.“In fact, more people are driving and LTNs have contributed to worsening congestion and pollution on surrounding roads. The irony is that this is a Labour council embracing a Tory policy.A Lambeth Council spokesman said: “Less dependence on motor vehicle use means we can reduce air pollution and improve air quality. The need for urgent action was clear at the start of the coronavirus pandemic, but it has been underlined in recent days by the warnings about the climate emergency, coming from Cop26, the annual UN climate conference.“There is no evidence to suggest that LTNs, established to help reduce traffic, improve road safety and enable active travel such as walking or cycling, have contributed to an increase in parking permits.We believe the number of permits issued increased for a number of reasons – including the introduction of Estate Permits into our system in 2020, and also a temporary shift in citizens moving to vehicles during the pandemic because of the restrictions and confidence in public transport. A new controlled parking zone in Streatham Hill and the extension of part of the Tulse Hill scheme on their own accounted for a 2.4 per cent increase.”More from NewsQueen pulls out of Cenotaph Remembrance Sunday service after spraining backWe must prepare for triggering Article 16Queen pulls out of Cenotaph Remembrance Sunday serviceFive lessons from Cop26 (that it didn’t mean to teach us)Protest erupts in Dutch city on first night of new lockdownMy best friend died in an air raid. title: must stand together freedom democracy
story: We believe in freedom and democracy. Freedom-loving societies are not just the best places to live, they are the most successful. When the Berlin Wall fell and the Iron Curtain came crashing down three decades ago, renewed democracies were established across eastern Europe. People have become freer, living better lives and their children have better futures. But these hard-won gains are now at risk with malign, autocratic regimes seeking to take away people’s freedom.Look at what’s happening in Belarus. The escalating stand-off at the Polish border marks the latest step by the Lukashenko regime to undermine regional security. He is using desperate migrants as pawns in his bid to create instability and cling on to power, regardless of the human cost.The United Kingdom will not look away. We will stand with our allies in the region, who are on the frontier of freedom. That’s why we are proud to be the first European country to assist Poland by agreeing to send a small team of personnel to provide engineering support to ease pressure at the border.In the same way, we were the first European country to put sanctions on the Lukashenko regime, targeting more than 100 iniduals and organisations with measures including asset freezes and travel bans. This shows we are ready to take the lead in standing up for freedom and democracy, acting robustly, decisively and relentlessly to take on malign actors wherever they are in the world.We are not just standing side by side with Poland as it bears the brunt of this shameful manufactured migrant crisis, but also the others in the Visegrad Four – Hungary, Slovakia and the Czech Republic – and our friends in the Baltics and Ukraine.In Belarus, this carefully crafted crisis is an attempt to ert attention away from the litany of abhorrent acts and human rights violations that the regime has already committed. Since the fraudulent election in August 2020, we have seen members of the opposition, journalists and activists beaten, jailed and killed, while others have been forced into exile.In contrast to their tyrannical leaders, the people of Belarus are true democrats. We have seen ordinary citizens risking everything to stand up for their rights and keep the flame of freedom alive. As the chairman of the Belarusian Association of Journalists, Andrei Bastunets, said: “Today, the law does not defend us. Today, we defend the law.” Russia has a clear responsibility here. It must press the Belarusian authorities to end the crisis and enter into dialogue.We need to fight for the rule of law, freedom and democracy, and we must take that fight to where that ideological battle is. Security is no longer solely about military hardware. The battle is now taking place in cyberspace, the economy and in the appalling use of people as collateral.We will join forces with our partners to advance our shared interests. At the Nato foreign ministers’ summit in Riga in a few weeks’ time, we will put forward new proposals to challenge the 21st-century methods of aggression being used by those who threaten our freedoms, economies and democracies.The world is changing and modern threats are more complex. That idea lies at the heart of the Integrated Review of security, defence, development and foreign policy the Government published earlier this year. We need to work with allies who believe we must have a world where freedom-loving democracies don’t just survive, but thrive.That is why we remain the largest European spender on defence in Nato – the world’s greatest defence alliance. It is why we are working with friends and allies in south-east Asia, where we are deepening our defence, maritime and security ties. This week in Indonesia, the world’s third-largest democracy, I agreed new ties in cyber. I also visited Thailand and Malaysia, where our co-operation includes the Five Power Defence Arrangements. We are also increasing our defence collaboration with India, Israel and many others around the world. Through Aukus we are collaborating with the US and Australia on the next generation of technologies.I want our friends across Europe to join us. That means standing together, for example in opposing the construction of the Nord Stream 2 pipeline. It risks undermining European security by allowing Russia to tighten its grip on those nations who rely on its gas, despite the pandemic reminding us about the importance of having erse supply chains to avoid being strategically dependent on unreliable partners.At this critical time, we should be deepening our investment and trade ties with countries that follow the rules and allow free-market economies to thrive. We cannot, and will not, ever give succour to those who want to undermine freedom and democracy.Together with our friends and allies, we can build a network of liberty, working to repel these malign actors to ensure freedom-loving people can live in peace.More from NewsQueen pulls out of Cenotaph Remembrance Sunday service after spraining backWe must prepare for triggering Article 16Queen pulls out of Cenotaph Remembrance Sunday serviceFive lessons from Cop26 (that it didn’t mean to teach us)Protest erupts in Dutch city on first night of new lockdownMy best friend died in an air raid. title: must prepare triggering article 16
story: After Covid restrictions, petrol crises and climate change extremists blocking roads and letting down tyres, the last thing anyone wants is to upend our trade relations with the EU. Unfortunately, that is what triggering Article 16 would entail (the EU side has even threatened a trade war) and it is an eventuality for which the Prime Minister must prepare. If Boris Johnson fails to do so, he will utterly undermine his own position in trying to renegotiate the Northern Ireland Protocol.That lesson was surely learned during Theresa May’s failed Brexit negotiations. She started out well, declaring that “no deal is better than a bad deal”. But then she went on to make no preparations for a “no deal” exit, making it plain to Michel Barnier and his team that under no circumstances would she ever allow it to happen. Barnier calculated, correctly, that this would allow him to treat May with contempt and lined up Britain for what the then-foreign secretary Boris Johnson called “punishment beatings”.In his own Brexit negotiations as Prime Minister in the autumn of 2019, Johnson was more serious about preparing for no deal, though the fact that he agreed to erect an internal border between Britain and Northern Ireland is the reason we are in such a mess now.He should not make the same error of allowing the EU to dictate terms again. Rather he should prepare for the economic dislocation and likely trade war that would be precipitated by triggering Article 16 by getting ready to do everything that the EU would least want us to do. This would involve an emergency Budget to slash taxes and deregulate –  we have hardly varied from any EU laws yet, which raises the question of why Johnson was so keen to leave in the first place. He should also target EU companies specifically with tax breaks to encourage them to relocate, and offer fast-track visas to any EU citizen who has a wealth-creating, job-creating business. In short, he should be prepared to turn Britain into what the EU feared most: a Singapore moored 20 miles off Calais.Britain should be laying the diplomatic groundwork, too. The idea that we would be somehow breaking international law by dumping the Protocol is bunk. Article 16 was written into the withdrawal agreement so that either side could unilaterally suspend the agreement in whole or in part if it was found to be causing “economic, societal or environmental difficulties”.This is clearly the case in Northern Ireland – and the Government, including our ambassadors around the world, should not be afraid to say so. As for Joe Biden, who would be sure to kick up a stink, Johnson needs to ask the US President every time he opens his mouth on the subject: how would he feel if some other country had the power to force him to put up a hard border between Delaware and the rest of the US?No one should want a trade war with the EU to happen. But to prepare for that outcome now is the only way we are going to dig Northern Ireland out of the deep hole into which it has been dumped.More from NewsQueen pulls out of Cenotaph Remembrance Sunday service after spraining backQueen pulls out of Cenotaph Remembrance Sunday serviceFive lessons from Cop26 (that it didn’t mean to teach us)Protest erupts in Dutch city on first night of new lockdownMy best friend died in an air raid. title: i work peter sutcliffe ian
story: I work with Peter Sutclfe, Ian Brady and Dennis Nilsen... not all killers are evilForensic psychologist Kerry Daynes, , doesnt believe that all infamous British killers are evil. Shes worked with some of the most famous killers in our country, such as Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutclfe, Moors Murderer Ian Brady and necrophile Dennis NilsenKerry Daynes has been a forensic psychologist for  yearsByKirsten JonesFeatures  Lestyle Writer:,  Nov | comments Wolfing down my chicken kebab supper, I look around the table and idly wonder what most folk would make of my fellow diners – a collection of ex-murderers, sex offenders and arsonists.But I’m not frightened. It’s  and part of my job is spending time in this “halfway house” in a busy northern city.Imy empty plate to Nigel, a shy man who’s washing up. Suddenly, I feel a blow to my stomach. Nigel has stabbed me with a in kebab skewer.He looks panicked, eyes flicking from side to side. I remain calm, staggering to the staff office while blood seeps through my white blouse.“Call an ambulance!” I gasp, slumping to the ground.I’ve been a forensic psychologist for  years, working with some of the most famous killers in our country, such as Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutclfe, Moors Murderer Ian Brady and necrophile Dennis Nilsen.  I use science and psychology to try and analyse people who commit crimes – from shoplting to shocking murders – and determinethey’re safe to be released from prison.I’ve always had a fascination with the macabre. As a child I read horror stories about killer grannies and watched Doctor Who from behind the sofa – monsters were about the only things that scared me. This career was my calling.I remember the first time I walked into a prison. It was Strangeways – now called HMP Manchester. I was a naive -year-old, keen to learn about crime psychology. It sounds cheesy, but I wanted to create a world with fewer victims in it.On my tour, the inmates started catcalling, “There’s some p***y on the wing!” The prison officer rolled his eyes at my confusion. He knew I’d be eaten alive.Two years later, in , I volunteered as a psychology assistant at Wakefield prison, nicknamed Monster Mansion by insiders. It’s full of sex offenders and murderers I’d only seen in the newspapers. I was feet away from parent killer Jeremy Bamber, Colin “Gay Slayer” Ireland and child murderer Terence McCready. It was utterly surreal yet I was so excited. This was long before the #MeToo movement and the male prison officers gave me a hard time. One day I interviewed a man who raped, strangled and murdered a woman. While we talked in the cell, the officers locked me in for a laugh.When I tugged at the door, it wouldn’t budge. Then it hit me… I was stuck in a room with a killer. I tried not to look frightened but I’m a redhead, I must have flushed like a tomato.He looked at me with a creepy smile. I was intimidated and genuinely scared – and he loved it. He said to me, “You’ve got a pretty neck, you know. It looks a lot like my victim’s.”I was only locked in for  minutes, but it felt like forever. Another inmate called out, “Are you alright in there, Miss ” adding, “I hope you’re treating her well.” That was his way of telling the inmate I was locked in with, “I’ll deal with youyou don’t.” I shook like a leaf that afternoon, but it didn’t put me off. Nowadays, I’m desensitised to a lot of things others would find completely paralysing. You’re probably used to seeing grey-haired men commenting on crimes on TV, but most forensic psychologists are women. People still think I chop up dead bodies for a living – that’s not my job. Nor am I running around the country trampling over crime scenes in my high heels and single-handedly arresting serial killers, like they do in TV dramas. Not all of my clients are dangerous, either. In  I worked with a -year-old named Frank Ecclestone, who confessed to a gruesome assault with a baseball bat. It was a messy case and the victim had almost died. Frank was regarded in the community as “a bit strange”. When I interviewed him, he was wearing a T-shirt featuring John Wayne Gacy – the “Killer Clown” who murdered at least  young men and boys. Not only did this quiet young man confess to the assault, he also blurted out that he was a serial killer and began headbutting the hospital wall. Afterwards, we were intercepted by another patient who had slit her wrist. My arm turned red as I gripped her wound to stem the flow. Meanwhile, Frank had gone a terrible shade of green. I knew he wasn’t a serial killer. Nor hadhe assaulted the victim. He was clearly scared of blood.Frank had given a  confession. It turned out that he had been raped by his stepmother as a child, and his little sister Holly was actually his daughter. His father threatened him and Frank confessed, “If I could say I was a killer he [Dad] would be scared to fight me.” To Frank, killers were powerful people who commanded attention and respect. Indeed, serial killers have become almost like pop-culture celebrities. I’ve been contacted by women who have US killer Ted Bundy’s teeth marks tattooed on their bodies – they think he was sexy! One day I was sitting on the sofa at home watching telly when the phone rang. I put the phone to my ear and heard a faint Scottish burr: “Hello Kerry, this is Dennis Nilsen.” I thought it was a wind-up, but it really was him. Dennis talked to me in graphic detail about his offences, keeping his fantasy alive. He spoke bitterly about his childhood in a Scottish fishing village, where he was bullied and was dishonest about his sexuality. He blamed a great deal of his dissatisfaction in le on his mother. Over four years he phoned me  more times. They were long, rambling telephone calls.Dennis loved to talk about himself and I wanted to understand his distorted version of the events that occurred at Melrose Avenue and Cranley Gardens in London. He’d revel in the TV shows about him. Receiving telephone calls and text messages from offenders and victims is common – you wouldn’t believe how many I’ve had. So Dennis’s chats weren’t that surprising. I now have Callon my phone, because I never know who’s going to ring me. A few years ago, I really felt fear. I was on TV talking about Jeremy Bamber.Jeremy doesn’t like me – he claims I wrote  stories about him and that I was never a qualied psychologist, which is nonsense. Anyway, someone who was watching became my stalker.This man set up websites in my name, claiming to be a fan of mine – I’m a forensic psychologist, not Britney Spears! He wanted photographs and information about me and when I politely declined, he got angry and wrote awful things about me. He said I was the criminal, he knew the size of my breasts and described what I was wearing each day. He was physically watching me and I was terried. One day I found the words “Jill Dando” written on my fence and, behind it, the leless body of my cat. I was devastated by the death of my poor pet. I took the man to court myself and paid thousands to have the awful websites removed. Only then was he arrested and given a harassment warning. It was  and I felt more afraid at home alone than I ever did in a prison full of killers.I’m a single woman, so there’s no man to worry about me. And I didn’t tell my parents or sister about being stabbed with that kebab skewer – I didn’t want them to fret.But now, after  years in the business, I could tell my family anything and they’d take it in their stride. It’s only when I talk about my job that I realise how surreal it sounds, but after work I come home, do the washing up and watch Strictly like everyone .In the past I’ve spent a lot of time in therapy to stop me remembering crime scene photographs or the horrors that I’ve heard. But I’m not scared of anyone I’ve worked with – I find politicians far more frightening than murderers.I’ve met people who’ve done dreadful, unforgivable things, but I don’t believe they are evil. It’s my job to find those human drivers behind inhuman behaviour. Every person has a story.What Lies Buried: A Forensic Psychologist’s True Stories Of Madness, The Bad And The Misunderstood by Kerry Daynes is out now Comment MORE ON Jill DandoTed BundyJohn Wayne GacyDennis NilsenHospitalsPrisonsSerial killersCrimeTherapyBullyingKne crimeSexuality" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: geoffrey cox accused feathering nest
story: Geoffrey Cox accused of feathering his nest as voters in Torys constituency hit outConservative MP Sir Geoffrey Cox has been facing criticism over his work outside Parliament. Voters in Tavistock, in his Torridge and West Devon constituency, share their viewsFormer Attorney General Sir Geoffrey Cox Image: REUTERSByChristine Grfin:,  Nov | commentsTory MP Sir Geoffrey Cox has been under fire this week after he was accused of using his parliamentary office for his £million-a-year second job. The former Attorney General was reported to the standards watchdog when footage emerged of him appearing to use his Commons office for his work advising the Government of the British Virgin Islands on a corruption probe triggered by the UK. Sir Geoffrey, who has practised as a QC since before his election in , put out a defiant statement denying that he had broken any rules, and said he had been clear about his work as a leading barrister. In a statement, his office said: Sir Geoffrey’s view is that it is up to the electors of Torridge and West Devon whether or not they vote for someone who is a senior and distinguished professional in his field and who still practices that profession. That has been the consistent view of the local Conservative Association and although at every election his political opponents have sought to make a prominent issue of his professional practice.  It has so far been the consistent view of the voters of Torridge and West Devon. Sir Geoffrey is very content to abide by their decision. But some voters in Tavistock, a market town in his Torridge and West Devon constituency, took a dferent view. Heaposs feathering his nest Tavistock Foodbank volunteer Brian Eales said he had voted Tory in the past but he was unhappy with the party now. Mr Eales, , said: I’ve never seen Geoffrey Cox at the foodbank in support. I did see him before my father passed away at the care home. He did visit there quite a lot but that was about  years ago. He’s not been seen recently in the office he’s got in Tavistock.  We don’t know what he does with his money do we. I’d like to think that with the sort of money he’s earning he’s making good use of, but he’s not. That’s a dferent kettle of fish. I’ve voted Conservative before but at the moment I wouldn’t vote for them, no. I’d be interested to find out what he is doing with the money. At the moment it seems to be all ‘self’, feathering his own nest shall we call it  I would be hurtI was a foodbank user by the lack of empathy Suzanne Weston, another volunteer in the foodbank cafe, said she thought Sir Geoffrey should stand down. Ms Weston, , said: What’s he’s doing is disgusting, absolutely outrageous and he’s supposedly our MP. He’s earning enough money as it is, and with the best will in the world nobody can do two full-time jobs at once. He can’t be putting his constituency work first while he’s over in the Caribbean, when we’re all having to be careful over here.  “I would imagine that many of the food bank clients are pretty upset about it. If I was in the awful position of having to come to the foodbank, I would be so hurt that someone in his position was not being more empathic towards my situation, just through his practical actions. I have never voted Tory nor would I ever. Although I know that there is always something going on in government, I just think this is awful.” He may have taken a step too far Penelope Tanner, , said he should be appearing more often in his constituency. The retired former councillor said: I think Geoffrey Cox is an extremely talented professional person who may have taken a step too far, but he was asked by the Government to take up his position.  “I feel he could appear in person a bit more often in his constituency here and his work should be measured. I think the Government has lost its way… they should be setting an example to the country particularly now with Covid. He shouldnapost resign - but he has abused his position -year-old Phil Hellier said Sir Geoffrey needed to think about ordinary folk in his constituency. I don’t think he should resign, but he’s abused his position and he should be thinking about what he could be doing for the ordinary person in the street, she said.  There’s not ever a day goes by when we don’t hear something and we’re not talking about small sums of money! There are people going without and he should put his constituency first. He lives here and I have heard he’s helped with local causes and done all he can to help. I’m dumbfounded with the lot of them. Itaposs ok to do another job Farmer Steve Vincent said he would still back Sir Geoffrey. The -year-old said: “I don’t know him, but I would still support him. If he’s doing another job that’s OK as long as he’s paying his taxes, there’s no reason why not to.  Itaposs not a crime as long as he delivers what heaposs supposed to Paul Reid, , said the MP was fine to have another job as long as he was meeting his commitments. He said: “It’s not obvious that he’s broken any rules. There’s a fine line, I work from home and occasionally I’ll manage to do a few other things. It’s not a crime as long as he delivers what he’s supposed to. Assuming he’s doing everything he should do, he seems experienced in what he’s doing.”   Iaposm appalled by the situation Angela Evans, , said it was wrong for the MP to be off earning large sums of cash outside of the area. She said: “I’m personally appalled by the situation. I would not want him to be ed to office and I feel really strongly about this. In fact, we emailed his office a couple of days ago to say how wrong it is that he is over in the British Virgin Islands and that he is not giving his effort and time to his constituents.  “On the surface Tavistock is seemingly a wealthier town compared to some towns but there are signicant amounts of people who are not making ends meet, and they are working but they still cannot make ends meet and there are signicant numbers of people who are homeless, and many are ‘sofa surfing’. “I think he’s quite good at appearing benevolence in front of cameras, but I think it’s quite shallow. I feel very angry about it. It just feels wrong to me to be off earning huge amounts of money and not even in the area. I’ve never voted for him.” Comment MORE ON Geoffrey CoxCare homesPoliticsHomelessness" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: gina tonic matt hancock lover
story: Exclusive: Matt Hancocks lover bins bottles of booze outside lovenest before sharing kissWhile the country is still in the grip of the pandemic, Mr Hancock and Gina Coladangelo are happily enjoying time at their new lovenestGina Coladangelo puts a bag of bottles in the bin Image: colin jackByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsEmpty booze bottles are binned by Matt Hancock’s lover – then the couple share a kiss just like the one that cost him his job. While the country is still in the grip of the pandemic, Mr Hancock and Gina Coladangelo are happily enjoying time at their new lovenest. The former Health Secretary, , has a flat in a two-storey block in West Hampstead, North London. And married Ms Coladangelo, his former aide, has been coming to stay overnight. She was spotted hauling a large bag of empties into the bin. Father-of-three Mr Hancock, meanwhile, went out to his car to take out boxes full of his stuff, before heading off to work.Days later they were seen sharing an embrace at the door after Gina, , had taken the bins out again. They locked lips, just as they did in the MP’s office back in June, when social distancing did not seem to be uppermost in their minds. Mr Hancock, who had presided over the Government’s shambolic handling of the pandemic, later fell on his sword and resigned. Neighbours in West Hampstead say the couple look very happy together. One said: “Wasn’t it Theresa May who said that taking the bins out was a boy’s job  Looks like Matt’s turned that on its head. “It looks like they’ve settled in pretty quickly, and they’re obviously really cosy with each other.”The pair have enjoyed two getaways in recent weeks – to the Swiss Alps and Croatia. Mr Hancock’s marriage of  years to we Martha broke down in the wake of the CCTV clinch scandal.At the time he said: “The last thing I would want is for my private le to distract attention from the single-minded focus that is leading us out of this crisis. “I reiterate my apology for breaking the guidance, and apologise to my family and loved ones for putting them through this. I also need to be with my children at this time.” Gina is a mother of three. Her children and husband Oliver Tress – founder of retail chain Oliver Bonas – live in the £.million family home in Wandsworth, South London.aposHeaposll need a stf drink once the inquiry startsapos - Analysis, by Nigel Nelson No wonder Matt Hancock is hitting the bottle. Not only did he lose the extra £, a year he was paid on top of his MP salary for his Health Secretary job. But soon after that he was disqualied from another one. And the only outside earnings he has been able to make to fund his new home is £, from a newspaper article. Though he is trying to negotiate a £, book deal. Not that he would have been quids in with the UN role helping Africa’s economy recover from Covid – as it was unpaid. But it would have given him the kudos he needs to rebuild his shattered political career. The UN withdrew last month’s offer after finding an obscure rule which says sitting MPs are prohibited from the post – and Africa was spared. Now Hancock will need a few more stf drinks before the sleaze row rocking Westminster engulfs him, too. It will not be long before his own cronyism is back under the microscope. The National Audit Office said half the £billion on pandemic contracts was awarded without competitive tender. Even the MP’s local pub landlord won a deal for Covid tests. Nothing to do with me, guv, said Hancock. And he’d better get a good stock of hooch in before the public inquiry into the pandemic begins as flowers bloom next spring. He won’t come up smelling of roses. PPE shortages, the test and trace fiasco and discharging patients with Covid back into care homes are mistakes likely to be laid at his door. A Cabinet   I think not.Comment MORE ON United NationsNational Audit OfficeTheresa MayCCTVCare homesCCTV footageNursing homesPublic inquiryPoliticsMatthew Hancock MP" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: insulate britain activists face six
story: Insulate Britain activists face six months in prison for superglue motorway protestsAnd police will also get new powers to stop and search for gluethey suspect it will be used in protests. Image: REUTERSByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor:,  Nov | commentsInsulate Britain protestors are to face six month jail for supergluing themselves to motorways. And police will also get new powers to stop and search for gluethey suspect it will be used in protests. Priti Patel plans on Monday to increase the penalties for disrupting Britain’s M-Way network from the present fine of just £,. The Home Secretary said: “It is totally unacceptable that police should be spending their days ungluing faces from dangerous roads. “They should be in our communities protecting the vulnerable people who need them most.” The necessary legal changes to include unlimited fines will be made in the Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill now going through Parliament.  Mr Patel said current penalties are not enough of a deterrent for organisations determined to cause widespread disruption.Environmental campaign group Insulate Britain has caused months misery which stopped people from getting to work by causing massive traffic jams.The sick were prevented from getting to hospital after getting caught up in the chaos.  And in their first four weeks of protests, the group cost the Met £ million in wasted policing funds as they made  arrests.. Ms Patel added: “Nobody should have unchecked rights to endanger the public. “There are legitimate ways in which activists can peacefully campaign for meaningful change.” Courts will get new powers to issue Serious Disruption Prevention Orders to stop serial offenders attending future protests. title: keir starmer man you can
story: Keir Starmer is the man you can trust to clean up dirty politicsWhile the Prime Minister has been focused on trying to get his Conservative Party mates off the hook and with no apology in sight, Sir Keir has a plan to sort out the mess Image: PAopinionByWes Streeting:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThere’s something rotten in the Conservative Party. It started with the Prime Minister changing the rules to save his mate. Owen Paterson has now resigned, but not before hundreds of millions of pounds of taxpayers’ money was paid to Randox, the company paying Paterson to lobby the Government. The Government continued to award Randox Covid contracts after the company was forced to recall up to , test kits because they weren’t up to scratch. We need an inquiry into whether Paterson’s lobbying influenced the Government’s decision to hand over millions in public funds without tender. Paterson may be gone, but the sleaze story is going nowhere. Reports suggest one in four Tory MPs are moonlighting in second, third and even fourth jobs.  Many look to be cashing in on their connections and insights as former ministers, while others are speaking in the House of Commons on issues relating to their employers. Cash for questions is back. Now it’s emerged that a Tory MP has been taking money from a firm caught up in Chinese state-surveillance claims. Is there no opportunity to line their pockets that these Tories won’t take  It’s hard to know where to start with Geoffrey Cox, who has been heard from just twice in two years in the House of Commons.  Not only has he been doing a full-time job, earning a fortune and failing to put his constituents first, Cox has been working on behalf of a tax haven, the British Virgin Islands, facing allegations of corruption. And it appears the whole thing has been sanctioned by the Government’s Chief Whip. That Cox is working to defend a tax haven really sticks in the throat. His colleague Adam Afriyie is currently facing potential bankruptcy for unpaid taxes. Yet both MPs loyally voted through the Conservative Government’s tax increases on working families. As the revelations have unfolded, Boris Johnson looks paralysed. He won’t apologise. He has no plan to clean up politics. It’s not clear whether he understands that what his MPs have been up to is wrong. Don’t forget, he described his own outside earnings of £, a year as “chicken feed”. I had £ to my name when I was first elected to Parliament. Compare and contrast with Keir Starmer. Before he came into politics, Keir headed up the Crown Prosecution Service. He took the decision to prosecute MPs who cheated on their expenses, ensuring they faced jail time. Throughout his career, he spent much of his time doing unpaid work for causes he believed in – standing up for ordinary people against powerful interests.  And while the Prime Minister has focused on trying to get his mates off the hook, Keir has a plan to clean up our politics. Ban MPs from paid consultancies and directorships. Ban ministers from taking on lobbying gigs for five years. And set up an Office for Value for Money, to make sure that every pound of taxpayers’ money is spent wisely. I know who I trust to clean up this mess. Comment MORE ON House of CommonsConservative PartyWes StreetingOwen PatersonBoris JohnsonGeoffrey CoxAdam AfriyiePoliticsTory GovernmentSunday Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: matt hancock considering 100000 deal
story: Matt Hancock considering £, deal on How I Won the Covid War bookShamed ex-Cabinet Minister Matt Hancock is reportedly in talks with HarperCollins about writing a book detailing his role in the Covid pandemic, which he describes as heroicFormer Health Secretary Matt Hancock is reportedly considering writing a book about the Covid pandemic Image: Getty ImagesBySam TrueloveNews reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsMatt Hancock is reportedly considering writing a book about aposhow he won the Covid warapos. The former Health Secretary wants to reveal all on his aposheroicapos role in the UK vaccine campaign, as well as aposheatedapos lockdown rows with ministers, aides, scientists and medics.Mr Hancock, who the Prime Minister called aposf***ing hopelessapos during his time as Health Secretary, is said to be in talks with HarperCollins about the book, which could earn him around £,, the Daily Mail reports.Itaposs reported the book will give Mr Hancock the chance to dispute claims that he was to blame for key blunders in the pandemic, and also hit out at former No  aide Dominic Cummings, who accused him of incompetence.Mr Hancock last night told the Mail: I have been approached to write a book, but no decisions have been made. The shamed ex-Cabinet Minister is believed to want the book published just before the official Covid inquiry starts in the spring. Got a story  Email webnews@mirror  According to the Mail, Mr Hancock intends to portray himself in a aposheroic lightapos and aposget his version of events out thereapos before he faces the inquiry. The former Health Secretary was forced to resign in June for breaching his own Covid restrictions when pictures emerged of him in a clinch with adviser Gina Coladangelo.Mr Hancock’s affair was exposed after The Sun published CCTV footage from inside the Tory MP’s office, showing the couple - who have known each other since university - enjoying a steamy kiss. He faced a barrage of calls to resign, after breaching the special distancing guidelines he had helped to establish as Health Secretary, and despite having the full support of Prime Minister Boris Johnson, Mr Hancock resigned just days after his affair hit the headlines. He has since left his we.According to the Mail, Mr Hancock is keen to resist pressure to use the book to describe the affair with aide Gina Coladangelo that led to his resignation in June. Instead, itaposs believed he will use the book to take aim at Mr Cummings, and elaborate on the claim that Mr Cummingsapos aposdestructive anticsapos delayed the vaccine breakthrough. Itaposs thought he will also take aim at EU Commission president Ursula von der Leyen over Covid jab rows. A well-placed source told the Mail: Matt paints a picture of a man burning the midnight oil night after night, staying cool under fire, saving the NHS and rising above petty Downing Street squabbles.If you believe the book, the vaccine is all down to him for backing it against all odds, treating anti-vaxxers with contempt and winning over a sceptical public. Mr Hancock also may reportedly go out of his way to be flatteringapos about Mr Johnson in the book, which some say is a clear sign that he is determined to win back his seat at the Cabinet table. Mr Hancockaposs handling of the Covid pandemic has come under scrutiny in the past, most notably after he claimed to have thrown a protective ring around care homes, only for Covid to rip through care homes after many elderly people were discharged from hospitals to free up beds. This resulted in thousands of people dying. He was at one stage branded aposf***ing hopeless’ by the Prime Minister, while on another occasion he absurdly denied a scarcity of PPE led to anyone dying on the Covid frontline. The news of the book deal comes after Mr Hancockaposs attempt to mount a political comeback faltered when the United Nations withdrew an offer of a job as a top envoy to Africa. Mr Hancock boasted of his appointment as an unpaid “UN special representative on financial innovation and climate change” for the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa. But the job offer was cancelled amid a furious public backlash. It also came the same day that a highly critical joint probe by the Commons health and science committees found Mr Hancock had presided over one of the most important public health failures in UK history at the start of the pandemic. The report found ministers had made a “serious error” by taking a sluggish approach to imposing lockdowns last year. A spokesperson for Matt Hancock said: “Matt has been approached to write a book about his experiences in the pandemic, but no decisions have been made. There is no deal. The people who were heroic during the pandemic were the NHS staff who worked round the clock to save lives.” Comment MORE ON HarpercollinsBoris JohnsonPoliticsMatthew Hancock MPCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: only spending can fix britains
story: Only spending can fix Britains terrying mental health crisisAs it emerges that thousands of mental health patients are straining the NHS and waiting too long for help, the Government must start undoing the damaging cutsThousands of mental health patients are straining the NHSImage: Getty Images iStockphotoopinionByVoice of the People:,  Nov | commentsEvery  seconds, someone calls  for a mental health emergency – a frightening statistic that brings home the scale of the crisis. For too long, mental health has been ignored, treated as less important than physical health. But attitudes have changed and we all realise its importance. All, it seems, except the Government. The last decade or so of Tory rule has seen mental health provision slashed to the bone. Services have gone, units closed, beds disappeared. Those in charge have been careless. It’s bad enough during normal times. But in a pandemic it’s downright dangerous.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section  Now the seeds they have sown are bearing fruit. Last year every hospital had , people in a mental health crisis brought to AE by ambulance. That’s a % jump since . The system couldn’t cope anyway. Now it’s breaking. Ambulances are backing up outside hospitals, waiting lists are at all-time highs, paramedics and police are struggling to cope. The solutions are clear: proper funding for health services and proper provision for mental health, a revolution in social care, better pay and conditions for our health service staff. It’s a lot, but this Government has a knack of finding money when it needs to. This isn’t for a trip to the Cayman Islands though. This is big money to save our NHS, end the mental health crisis and enable our health service do what it does best: caring for people and saving lives. Meghan court out The beauty of the justice system is that it is blind. Rich or poor, those before the courts are judged on the facts of their case and nothing more. Even Meghan Markle is finding this out now. She “forgot” certain vital information during a hearing. What’s frightening for her is that others might now remember things that were forgotten. No-one wishes her ill. She has had a tough time of it in the past couple of years. But the courts are based on a system that applies to everyone. Even a Duchess. title: operation rampdown plan get rid
story: Operation Rampdown plan to get rid of self-isolation and mass testing by early Free Covid tests could be replaced with private companies charging for lateral flow and PCR tests and the £ payments for those on low incomes and forced to quarantine could also come to an endMass testing could come to an end as the Government considers its Covid strategy Image: Getty ImagesByKatie Mansfield:,  Nov | commentsThe Government is reportedly planning to stop self-isolation, mass testing and Test and Trace by early next year as part of a secret Covid exit plan dubbed Operation Rampdown. Free Covid tests could be replaced with private companies charging for lateral flow and PCR tests and the £ payments for those on low incomes and forced to quarantine could also come to an end. According to leaked documents, ministers are to abandon attempts to stop Covid- spreading aposat all costsapos. The exit strategy is said to be part of a six-week review of the Governmentaposs apostest, trace and isolate regimeapos by UK Health Security Agency as officials consider how le will look by April. According to a -page dossier leaked to the Mail on Sunday, Operation Rampdown will also scrap the legal requirement for people who catch Covid to isolate for ten days.The Test and Trace system could also be axed as the Government turns its focus to tackling local outbreaks and infections in high-risk place, such as care homes. In the document, experts warn while mutant strains will aposremain a very real riskapos and Covid will remain at aposendemicapos levels for years, itaposs predicted there will be aposno winter resurgenceapos.  One source told the Mail on Sunday that some health experts who have been on the frontline of the fight against Covid are now aposjust walking awayapos from Government. The source said: Itaposs totally over, in the minds of ministers. But what happensa new iant arrives and they have just shut down the whole national infrastructure  Are we retaining enough knowledge from the £ billion investment over the past two years  I really donapost think we are.It comes after Professor Neil Ferguson, a member of the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies , suggested Christmas restrictions will not be needed. He said he feels it is unlikely Britain will see a catastrophic winter wave similar to that seen last year, which led to months of further lockdown across the country. New data from the Office for National Statisticshas suggested infection levels are continuing to fall across the UK. The figures show about one in  people in private households in England had Covid- in the week to November , down from one in  the previous week. More than two million people received their Covid- booster in the past week, with health officials describing the numbers as record-breaking.The NHS is now inviting those who had their second dose more than five months ago for their booster, allowing people to book their top-up in advance of becoming eligible so they can receive it as soon as they reach six months.Comment MORE ON Mail on SundayCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: sleazy tories not just out
story: Sleazy Tories not just out of touch with normal people - theyre on a dferent planetIt is not just that the Tories are out of touch with ordinary people, they are on a dferent planet, and now it is down to decent Conservative politicians to rid us of this PM and the sleaze that seems to constantly surround himThe Tories are on another planet Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Nov | commentsThe stench of sleaze now stinking out the Conservative Party is up there with the MPs’ expenses scandal. The dference is this one was hiding in plain sight. The Register of Members’ Interests is packed with facts and figures on MPs’ outside earnings and the identities of companies paying them. But it is such a dry document few of us would choose it for our bedtime reading. It is only because Prime Minister Boris Johnson bungled an outrageous attempt to save the career of corrupt MP Owen Paterson that the spotlight is now shining on it. The MPs involved say the public does not carethey pocket a few quid on the side – even though a few quid in their world adds up to £.million in consultancies and directorships alone so far this year.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section That £.million is petty cash compared to the fortune Geoffrey Cox has raked in from legal fees representing a dodgy Caribbean regime. He can make in an hour what a Brit on average earnings of £, makes in a month. Andthe public does not care, MPs must have another explanation for their inboxes filling up with angry emails from constituents – unless they are too busy with second jobs to read them. If the public does not care, Labour must be doing a better job than the Tories give them credit for to take a six point lead in the polls. Homeowners struggling to pay mortgages on an average £, house care very much when the PM gives Michael Gove a £milllion one for free.  Nor will they be impressed with Tory MP Richard Fuller’s £, from a firm with links to Chinese surveillance. Or Boris dismissing £, from a second job as a newspaper columnist as “chicken feed”. It is not just that the Tories are out of touch with ordinary people. They are on a dferent planet. An election is too far away for voters to send them into orbit. But Mr Johnson should be brought to earth with a bump. It is down to decent Conservative politicians to rid us of this PM and the sleaze that seems to constantly surround him. And we wish them the greatest success in doing so. Meg’s mess... Meghan Markle’s claim that her privacy was invaded is undermined when she reveals herself as the one breaching it. Prince Harry’s we now “remembers” co-operating with the authors of a book about the couple’s personal lives. And having admitted doing so, Ms Markle now faces a possible privacy action herself from older sister Samantha. We accept Ms Markle found it a strain to marry into the world’s most famous family. But maintaining privacy requires consistency. So Ms Markle cannot put private matters into the public domain when it suits her. Because having her cake and eating it will just end in more tears.Comment MORE ON Conservative PartyMichael GoveOwen PatersonGeoffrey CoxBoris JohnsonPoliticsTory Government" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: tory geoffrey cox claims 1500
story: Exclusive: Tory Geoffrey Cox claims £, for  car trips to Commons but votes in person  TIMESThe Mirrors latest revelations come after a week of stinging criticism for Westminster’s top-earning MP, Sir Geoffrey Cox, and his work ethic has not impressed his constituentsSir Geoffrey claimed £. for a round trip Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByNick SommerladInvestigations Editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsSir Geoffrey Cox is facing fresh questions over sleaze after claiming almost £, in travel expenses for seven round trips to London in three months last year when he only voted in person on three days. On the other  days of voting in the House of Commons in that period, Mr Cox used an arrangement called a “proxy” to cast a vote without attending. During the same three months, from October to December , Mr Cox devoted  hours to four outside jobs which paid him a total of £,.At the end of this spell, PM Boris Johnson gave Mr Cox a knighthood for his “parliamentary and political service”.Sir Alistair Graham, former chairman of the committee on standards in public le, said: “At first sight of the evidence available, it appears that Sir Geoffrey has questions to answer. The appropriate authorities should look into this.”Have your say on these revelations in the comment section Our latest revelations come after a week of stinging criticism for Westminster’s top-earning MP, who has pocketed almost £million from legal work on the side since becoming member for Torridge and West Devon in . His work ethic has not impressed his constituents. Brian Eales, , a volunteer at Tavistock Food Bank, said: “I’ve never seen Geoffrey Cox at the food bank in support. At the moment it seems to be all self, feathering his own nest.” Business owner Suzanne Weston, , said: “Geoffrey Cox should stand down. What’s he’s doing is disgusting. Nobody can do two full-time jobs at once.” Angela Evans, , said: “I’m personally appalled by the situation. I would not want him to be ed to office.”  The Mirror examined Mr Cox’s record in the last quarter of  and found no evidence he spoke in Parliament or asked written questions and he was not listed on any parliamentary committees. He completed the -mile round trip by car from his constituency home in Tavistock, Devon, to London seven times in the three months and claimed £. from the taxpayer each way. Yet he voted in person in the House of Commons on just three days – October , November  and December . For  other Commons votes over  days of Parliamentary debate he used a proxy.  His register of interests shed light on what  he was doing during that time. Khan Partnership Solicitors in London paid him £, “for legal services provided between  November and  December ” totalling “ hrs approx”. The firm paid him £, “for legal services provided in November ” totalling “ hrs approx”. Khan paid him another “£, for legal services provided in October ” totalling  hours “approx”. At the end of September , Mr Cox received the first quarterly payment of £, from Withers LLP for “up to  hours a month”. He continues to receive a quarterly payment from the London firm. Mr Cox did not respond to a request for comment.  But a source close to the politician said: “During this period, Geoffrey was visiting London and the House of Commons approximately twice a month for one or two days to hold meetings with staff, MPs and deal with issues arising in his office.” Mr Cox has earned £, from extra work as a lawyer in  so far. He earned tens of thousands from the British Virgin Islands, advising the government of the Caribbean tax haven on corruption, while voting remotely in the Commons. On Thursday, the Mirror revealed that Mr Cox was earning tens of thousands of pounds a year renting out his London second home, while charging the taxpayer £, a month in rent for another place in the capital, which, like his extra work, is within the rules.  But Labour has asked the standards commissioner to investigate after it emerged Mr Cox had appeared to attend an online hearing of the British Virgin Islands corruption inquiry from his Commons office.Quizzed about Mr Cox on Sky News, Business Minister Paul Scully said: “I’m not going to defend Geoffrey. Absolutely, I can see how it looks.” On his website Mr Cox said he “does not believe he breached the rules”.The Met Police have ruled out an investigation into “cash for honours” claims that the Tories give peerages to donors who give the party huge sums.Comment MORE ON PoliticsGeoffrey CoxTory GovernmentExpensesConservative PartyMarcus RashfordBoris Johnson" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: tory mps 300000 link china
story: Exclusive: Tory MPs £, link to China spy firm as he gets £, for four extra jobsThe cash for extra jobs scandal grows as it emerges wealthy backbencher Richard Fuller MP has four roles outside Parliament and advised a company that invests in surveillance kit, with Labour expressing human rights fears on the spy techConservative MP Richard Fuller has four other jobs Image: Richard Townshend PhotographyByGeraldine McKelvieInvestigations Editor:,  Nov | commentsA Tory MP has received over £, from extra work – with a huge chunk coming from a firm which invests in spy technology in China.Richard Fuller is an advisory director for Investcorp – one of FOUR jobs on top of being an MP.The private equity firm has paid him more than £, while he has been an MP. Investcorp helped bankroll a firm which worked for the Chinese government on surveillance systems capable of tracking oppressed Uyghur Muslims. It is feared a million Uyghurs are held in “brainwashing” detention camps, that women have been sterilised and children taken away.  Articial intelligencecompany Sense Time said its technology could identy Uyghurs by facial recognition. Yet Mr Fuller, , sat on a parliamentary committee which examined treatment of the Uyghur people in Xinjiang – and recommended fines for UK firms using supply chains linked to the province.Mr Fuller – educated at Oxford and Hard – is MP for North East Bedfordshire. His earnings are within the rules, but the new details come as the Tories are mired in sleaze over extra income and Boris Johnson is under pressure to ban secondary jobs for his MPs. Last night Labour ’s deputy leader Angela Rayner said: “The corruption scandal that has engulfed the Conservative Party gets worse by the day.“We need an investigation to get to the bottom of whether this relationship has put our national ­security at risk and whether this technology has aided human rights abuses in China.”  MPs are paid £,. Mr Fuller’s additional income is extensive. In  he quit a post with software company Impero Solutions with a £, payoff. But he continued as an advisory director at £, a year for just two hours work a month. He also makes £, a year from OpSec Security and £, from software company Enviivo. He has worked for Investcorp on and off since . From - the register of MPs’ financial interests shows he received £,. He lost the Bedford seat in  but was elected in North East Beds two years later. Since then he has had £, – seven quarterly sums of £, plus £,, £, and £, for extra work. Hazem Ben-Gacem, co-CEO of global firm Investcorp, has given Mr Fuller £, in political donations since . Investcorp has pumped millions into technology firms in China.  In , it invested in the China Everbright Limited New Economy Fund. In  it started to jointly manage the fund, overseen by the Chinese government. A key beneficiary was Sense Time, which has done work for China’s powerful propaganda unit. In a  patent for a facial-recognition product, Sense Time stated: “It is possible to ide the ethnicities... according to Han, non-Han and unknown, or according to Han, Uyghur, non-Han, non-Uyghur, and unknown.” Investcorp also backed Terminus, an AI firm involved in fitting “surveillance cam-eras with image identication capability” in some Chinese cities. Last night a spokesman for Sense Time said its patent was “never designed” to “discriminate against any groups” and said it liaised with the UN and other international organisations. He added: “Such an action is a violation of our company values. The patent application was amended. We are committed to promoting the responsible and sustainable use of AI.” Alkan Akad, of Amnesty International, said: “There are grave human rights violations in China. Some include the use of extreme surveillance and articial intelligence. Companies have a responsibility to protect human rights.” Last night Mr Fuller said he was aware of our story but would not be commenting. He said: “My constituents will read your article andthey want me to respond I guess I can talk to them about it.” Comment MORE ON PoliticsChinaInvestcorp SAAmnesty InternationalUnited NationsConservative PartyMichael GoveBoris JohnsonHuman rightsSurveillanceSunday Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: christmas reindeer massacre sick firm
story: Exclusive: Christmas reindeer massacre as firm sparks fury with festive safaris for Brit huntersRussian winter safari company charges up to £, to shoot the Christmas favourite in Santa slaying of reindeer with guaranteed kills of the vulnerable animalsA hunter poses with a dead reindeerByChris McLaughlinPolitical reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsReindeer are as much a part of the festive season as Santa and his elves. But while kids will be painting pictures of them on their Christmas cards and singing the praises of Rudolph and his chums, British hunters will be paying up to £, to shoot them for kicks.Even more shockingly, the animals are officially classied as “vulnerable” and are already extinct in parts of Lapland. And scientists say hunting is one of the main reasons for their decline.The Santa slay holidays are being organised by a Russian winter safari company – whose website even features a grotesque image of a Christmas tree made of antlers from slaughtered beasts.  Other pictures show satisfied gun-toting ­customers proudly posing with slain reindeer, bears and other wildle in the snow. Adverts aimed at the lucrative UK market offer guided stalking holidays and guaranteed “kills”, starting at £, for seven-day reindeer hunts. Hunters wanting to take trophies such as antlers home to Britain will have to pay another £. “Mixed bags”, including bears, grouse, moose, wolves and lynx, rise in price, with a reindeer and moose package costing £,.  Anti-hunt groups have slammed the tours. Eduardo Goncalves, of the Campaign to Ban Trophy Hunting, said: “These sick serial animal killers spoil Christmas for children everywhere. “Rudolph and his mates pulling the sleigh are part and parcel of Christmas time for kids. Now it’s Rudolph lying dead in the snow. Reindeer may go extinctthings carry on as they are.” The hunts are organised by Baikal Royal Safari and take place in forests near Lake Baikal in southern Siberia. Participants are housed for up to a week in specially equipped hunting lodges or a “traditional hunting camp”, with saunas, wi-fi, skis, ­snow-mobiles, quad bikes and ammunition.  Online ads are designed to appeal to frequent hunters with their own weapons, such as rles and crossbows, and highlight reindeer special promotions over the Christmas period. Under a photograph of a gun-toting hunter and a slaughtered, bloodied stag with huge antlers, company owner Vladislav Lee promises “the most interesting and effective winter hunting in snow”. Under the terms of the deals, only high-calibre rles are allowed and promotional material stresses the price of any trophy “is not included”, but is negotiable. Advice on shipments of trophies is offered, as is the help of the company’s ­recommended taxidermist. Lee boasts the ­company was founded in  and operates in  Russian territories. Campaigners expect a Black Friday sale for the hunting trips to be online shortly.The hunts are legal in Russia and former leader Leonid Brezhnev was a keen participant. In Britain, the Safari Club International awards prizes for the highest number of reindeer kills chalked up by members. Its UK president, Steve Jones, said he had no connection with the Russian outfit but ­defended hunting and his company’s practice of making awards for kills. He said: “Critics are often ill-informed and motivated by financial or political gain. Hunting contributes to the protection of habitat and species that are threatened by ­poaching and human encroachment. Hunters enjoy making a valuable ­contribution.”  In , Mr Jones memorably clashed with presenter Piers Morgan when he appeared on breakfast TV to defend hunting because fans “enjoyed it”. Morgan threatened to shoot him with a bow and arrow, skin him alive and stick his body on a wall.Mr Jones is a former Tory mayor of Beaconsfield who defected to UKIP. In  he posted a snap of himself with Boris Johnson at a Tory party social event under the caption: “Out with my mate tonight.”The Prime Minister is under pressure to fulfil a two-year old vow to ban trophy imports. But a Bill has been delayed as Whitehall officials undertake a new round of consultation amid fears the new law will be watered down.  Campaigners fear a loophole will allow hunters to continue as normal for a “blood money” ­payment to conservation projects. Reindeer trophies such as antlers would still be legal under the proposed ban. The new law is likely to cover species listed on the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species’ list of animals threatened with extinction. But reindeer are classed as ­vulnerable on the red list of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature – just one level below endangered.Campaigners want future legislation to cover trophy imports from all species and Labour MP John Spellar is preparing his own Bill. It is backed by the Sunday People and a host of celebrities, including Ricky Gervais.The comic behind The Office and After Le spoke out when we ran a picture of a shot polar bear projected by campaigners at Glasgow’s COP climate summit.  Campaigner Mr Goncalves said: “Boris Johnson says he plans to ban hunting trophies from some species. We need a total ban to ­discourage these people from killing reindeer and other defenceless animals.” Mr Goncalves, who recently received a “ days of Xmas” offer for hunting gear from a trophy hunting newsletter, added: “You literally can’t make it up!” Shadow Environment Secretary Luke Pollard said: “Trophy hunting is cruel and unjustiable. We need to ban imports of trophies from ­endangered species now.” aposMy bill to ban sickosapos - Comment, by John Spellar, Labour MP for Warley I’, backing the Sunday People’s campaign to outlaw sick souvenirs of trophy hunting such as reindeer.Next month, I willbe putting a Bill before Parliament to put this in law and I’m now inviting the Government to support it.Many of us remember the magnicent creature Cecil, the lion shot in Zimbabwe by a trophy-hunting American dentist in . Following an international uproar, the Government said it would ban British hunters from bringing home lion trophies, then promised to outlaw ALL trophies of endangered species. But the ban never materialised. And now the Government has postponed its own legislation, saying there’s not enough time in its schedule. So I’m offering them a solution. The Government can adopt my Bill. That way, we get the ban they’ve promised – and which nine in  voters want. Disgracefully, since , the year Cecil was killed, another  lion trophies have been brought into the UK by British hunters.  In all, around , trophies of elephants, giraffes, zebras, and monkeys have been brought back to Britainsince then.British trophy hunters even brought back the body of a polar bear last year. Now a company is even offering sick hunters the chance to slaughter reindeer for Christmas So, Boris, let’s give wildle, and voters, something to cheer this Christmas. Let’s ban trophies from Britain now. title: dalmatian first dog catch covid
story: Dalmatian was first dog to catch Covid in UK - and he was left in agonyKips concerned owners Gareth and Alison Ayles-Owen took him to the vet and he tested positive for the Kent iant" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Dalmatian.jpg" width"" "" Kip caught Covid after his owners tested positive in October Image: Getty ImagesByKatie Mansfield:,  Nov | comments A Dalmatian was left in agony with breathing problems after becoming the first dog in the UK to catch Covid.Kipaposs concerned owners Gareth and Alison Ayles-Owen took him to the vet and he tested positive for the Kent iant. The family from South West London think nine-year-old Kip caught the virus when they had Covid in October .Vets at Ralph Veterinary Referral Centre in Marlow, Buckinghamshire checked Kit and Montpellier University in France carried out further analysis, confirming the diagnosis.Experts say there is no evidence the animal was involved in the transmission of the disease to its owners, or that pets or other domestic animals are able to transmit the virus to people.Alison told The Sun : “The family had Covid in October  and we think that is how Kip got infected. We thought it might be Covid because we heard a lot of people were suffering with heart arrhythmia but it was not thought pets could get it at the time.He was really poorly for a few weeks.” In line with international agreements, Kipaposs case was reported to the World Organisation for Animal Health. He has now fully recovered. The British Veterinary Association said: “Confirmed cases in cats and dogs worldwide remain rare and it’s highly likely that the transmission route was from infected owners to their pets, rather than the other way round.” Last week chief veterinary officer Christine Middlemiss said: There is no clear evidence to suggest that pets directly transmit the virus to humans. We will continue to monitor this situation closely and will update our guidance to pet owners should the situation change. Scientists in the Netherlands found that coronavirus -gtcoronavirus is common in pet cats and dogs where their owners have the disease and owners have previously been told to avoid their pets while infected.While cases of owners passing on Covid- to their pets bring negligible risk to public health, the scientists said there is a potential risk that domestic animals could act as a reservoir for coronavirus and reintroduce it to humans. title: helpful trick remove car windshield
story: Helpful trick to remove from car windshield in seconds and avoid £ fineMotorists shared a viral clip on social media site TikTok which shows how to quickly remove snow from your windscreen and allow the driver to be up and running and a way on their commuteClearing the windscreen after snowfall is always a tough job Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByGraeme Murray:,  Nov | commentsA genius trick to remove frost from your car in seconds and avoid £ fine has been shared by drivers As temperatures plummet across the country next week and snow is forecast to fall in some parts. Drivers who fail to clear their windscreens before they set off could earn themselves a £ fine and three points on their driving licence. To avoid splashing out on car covers and de-icing solutions, motorists have come up with a novel way of protecting their vehicle. Motorists shared a viral clip on social media site TikTok which shows how to quickly remove snow from your windscreen.  All that is required is an old blanket or towel, which are left on the car overnight. Thy are advised to put it over the windscreen and secure it beneath their wipers to avoid it blowing away during the night. They simply take off the cover in the morning and quickly remove ice and snow which may have fallen during the night. This allows motorists to go on their way with a clear windscreen and the prospect of getting a fine.  Other ways of avoiding snow and ice build-ups include planning your parking in advance. If you park with your front window pointing east, it will catch the sun rising in the morning and mother nature nature will do the hard work de-icing your car for you.The Mirror told of another shortcut to help drivers yesterday when a mum has praised herself for using carpet stain remover to quickly melt frozen windscreens.Angela Hickling shared a video of her wiping the ice off her car windshield using a bottle of Dr Beckmanaposs Carpet Stain Remover.. She told the Daily Record: Iaposm a genius. Get yourself one of these bottles, fill it with warm water and youaposre sorted. No cold hands scraping anymore and it cleans ya window screen to, the brush bit is ideal. Other tips motorists have suggested include putting plastic bags over wing mirrors overnight to avoid removing frost from them in the morning. But there are some aposshortcutsapos motorists should steer clear of, such as clearing a frosted window with boiling water which is likely to could you money in the long term. news uk-news jihadi-bride-shamima-begum-claims-"Shamima Begum wants fair trial after apologising for Manchester Arena attack commentsByKatie Mansfield:,  Nov | comments Jihadi bride Shamima Begum claims ISIS tried to firebomb her tent in a refugee camp and says she fears for her le.The -year-old is said to be a prime target for ISIS after suggesting she has denounced the terror group. Begum, who had her UK citizenship revoked by the Home Office on national security grounds in , travelled from East London to Syria in  when she was -years-old.She married jihadi Yago Riedijk and the couple had three children, who have all died.Begum has repeatedly said she wishes toto the UK and would rather die than go back to ISIS. She now lives in the Al-Roj camp in Syria and wears Western clothes.  Devout ISIS wives have reportedly vowed to kill her and Begum claims there was an arson attempt on her tent last week.A source told The Sun : “Wearing trainers and make-up has angered the wives.”It comes after her husband refused to condemn ISIS beheadings as he celebrated the coupleaposs aposbeautulapos le under the extremist group. He hopes to reunite with his we and start a family again. In an interview, he said ISIS-claimed attacks on the West were prohibited in Islam because they involved killing innocent people innocent people. But he would not criticise groupaposs violence against Yazidis and other Muslims.  Riedijk, , from the Netherlands said he could not comment when asked to condemn the groupaposs brutal punishments. He still hopes to see a caliphate which follows Islamic traditions. The Mirror told in September how Begum told friends she would refuse to name Brits involved in ISIS.Begum then insisted she was not a threat and begged toto the UK even suggesting she could help fight terrorism.  Appearing on ITV ’s Good Morning Britain on Wednesday  September, Begum, looked completely dferent from the first time she made headlines, where she wore a large black Chador.While appearing on-air, the young woman wore a snapback, covering her long and loose wavy hair, as well as a tank top and neon red painted nails. Begum is accused of stitching suicide bombers into explosive vests - an allegation she has denied. news uk-news kate-middleton-takes-queens-place-"Remembrance Sunday: Royals attend service at CenotaphByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe Duchess of Cambridge took centre stage as she watched the Remembrance Sunday service alongside the Duchess of Cornwall and Sophie Wessex today.Kate looked solemn as she stood in the middle with Camilla and Sophie at her sides on the balcony of the Foreign Office while Prince Charles, Prince William, Princess Anne and Prince Edward were below as they laid wreaths at the Cenotaph.However, missing from the balcony was the Queen, who has sprained her back and was unable to attend todayaposs Remembrance Sunday service.All three women were dress in black hats and coats that had poppies pinned to them. Kateaposs Alexander McQueen coat was one she had previously worn to the same event in . In previous years, the Queen had stood on the balcony at the centre of Kate and Camilla. Earlier today, Buckingham Palace said Her Majesty was disappointed to miss the event held annually at the Cenotaph in London.She was set to lead the nation in commemorating the war dead during her first in-person public engagement since going into hospital. Buckingham Palace insisted her back strain was not connected to the recent hospital stay where she was forced to spend the night at the King Edward VII in Marylebone last month to undergo “preliminary investigations” for an unknown condition. A royal source said: “It is the most unfortunate timing for Her Majesty who recently had a short break to Sandringham in Norfolk for a few days and was left feeling rested and recuperated on herto Windsor Castle. “On conversation with royal doctors it was decided that a back sprain is not conducive with a car journey and a period of standing.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. “Her Majesty is deeply disappointed to miss the ceremony.” The Queen has only ever missed six Remembrance Sunday events in her -year reign - four due to being abroad on royal tours and two when she was pregnant.  In a statement, the Palace said it was with great regret the Queen would be unable to attend the service. The statement said: The Queen, having sprained her back, has decided this morning with great regret that she will not be able to attend todayaposs Remembrance Sunday service at the Cenotaph. Her Majesty is disappointed that she will miss the service. As in previous years, a wreath will be laid on Her Majestyaposs behalf by The Prince of Wales. His Royal Highness, along with the Duchess of Cornwall, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, the Earl and Countess of Wessex, the Princess Royal and Vice Admiral Sir Tim Laurence, the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester, the Duke of Kent and Princess Alexandra will be present at the Cenotaph today as planned.
