title: £220k investment set to revitalise Church Street
story: DETAILS of the pound, investment initiative for an eagerly-anticipated revitalisation scheme at Church Street in Downpatrick have been revealed.Despite being the main gateway into the town centre, the area has largely missed out on public sector investment over recent years.Signicant investment has been pumped into neighbouring Market Street, Irish Street and Scotch Street, with Church Street the poor relation when it came to so-called public realm schemes.But that is set to change with the Department for Communities and Newry, Mourne and Down Council providing the cash for an exciting new initiative.The government department is already heavily involved in the regeneration of the former police base at Irish Street in the town and while progress has been slow, there are hopes that progress can be made in the near future.A steering group has been formed to detail how the pound, will be spent in Church Street with a draft plan sent to businesses at this part of the town and local councillors.An examination of the plan reveals that pound, has been earmarked for a shop front improvement scheme with the emphasis on painting and repairing existing facades.Elsewhere, itrsquos proposed to spend pound, on what is being described as a ldquoconcept design of Church Street with the work due to be carried out by a consultant, with pound, earmarked for improving shop fronts in Bridge Street.Fteen thousand pounds has been earmarked for De Courcey Place in English Street to replace a number of heritage-style lamps and signposts, alongside the provision of new litter bins and planting out existing granite water troughs. The area will also be power washed.Just over pound, is to be spent on other planting and landscaping schemes in the Church Street area, while there are also proposals for a new bus stop and power washing the area outside the former telephone exchange.New safety railings are to be installed outside  Church Street, while a mural will be painted on one of the gable walls at the entrance to the car park at this part of the town.There are also plans to invest pound, on new interpretation material highlighting the Tower Bell at Down Parish Church and the grave of United Irishman Thomas Russell in the church grounds.Plans have also been outlined to provide new festive lighting on the side of the Down Arts Centre and on trees in De Courcey Place.The draft plan confirms a proposal to appoint a quantity surveyor to oversee the substantial investment with hopes that the work can start as soon as the document secures approval from the steering group.Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran has welcomed the opportunity business and property owners are being given to revitalise what he described as a key part of the town.ldquoThe proposed Church Street investment is welcome news in a part of the town where there are a number of family-owned businesses whose links with Downpatrick stretch back over several generations, he said.ldquoThe draft plan provides a vision for the future and business owners welcome the signicant investment which will considerably help Church Street which has missed out on funding for some considerable time.Cllr Curran said the revitalisation scheme provided a firm  on which to build for the future and he hoped that business and property owners will be encouraged to spend some of their own money on their respective properties to make them even better.He is also keen to see progress on the Irish Street scheme which has not made the progress many would have hoped by this stage.Cllr Curran added: ldquoRedeveloping the former police base site and neighbouring properties will be a game-changer and act as a catalyst to secure more investment, increasing footfall which will benefit existing traders.ldquoDownpatrick is a county town and its status warrants not only a vibrant retail hub, but a place where all buildings look smart and welcoming.ldquoSignicant sums of money have been invested in other town centre streets and I am delighted that it is now Church Streetrsquos turn to benefit from some much-needed, but very welcome investment..prettyPhoto

title: Aughlisnafin make history
story: AUGHLISNAFIN were crowned junior champions for the first time in their  year history after a pulsating contest with Dundrum concluded in a three-point victory at Pairc Esler on Friday night.Despite a commendable second half surge from John Clarkersquos Dundrum men, the lsquoFin showed their experience in the competition and managed to cling on to achieve intermediate status for next yearrsquos campaign.Dundrum began on the offence straight from the start, winning the throw-in and immediately attacking the opposition.This set the tone for what would be a highly paced and energetic contest, as Aughlisnafinrsquos Oran Flanagan fouled Dundrumrsquos Michael McGrattan for a free within the opening minute.However, what should have been a straight forward conversion was missed by Cormac Venney.Breannain McComiskey immediately made Venney rue his miss, as the Aughlisnafin man kicked over the bar following good build-up play from Shea Croskery for the opening score of the final.The lsquoFin kept their foot on the pedal and won the following kick-out, with Flanagan making up for his earlier foul to convert a point from play.Referee Conor Curran was kept busy throughout the game and first brandished his yellow card just four minutes in to Aughlisnafinrsquos Noel Travers after a sloppy high tackle.Following patient build up play, Croskery added his sidersquos third point of the game, with Dundrum now desperate to get on the board.It was clear nerves were playing a part in the early stages, as Venney failed to convert another free wide, this time dragging his shot right of the posts.With Aughlisnafin piling the pressure on the Dundrum defence the ball was worked back to lsquokeeper Walsh who played a fist pass out to team-mate Thomas McShane  metres from goal.However, disaster struck as the Dundrum man fumbled the ball in the danger area, allowing Flanagan to pick up the scraps and bury the ball into the back of the net to give The lsquoFin a six point lead less than ten minutes in.Michael McGrattan tried to answer for Dundrum but saw his effort drt wide before custodian Walsh finally got his side off the mark with a converted free.McComiskey replied sharply, notching his second point by kicking over the black spot from open play, although Venney did answer this with a point of his own that he desperately needed just before the water-break.At the conclusion of the opening quarter, Aughlisnafin were by far the dominant side and led - to -.On the restart Dundrum managed to find their groove and make up for earlier mistakes courtesy of successive points from Venney and McGrattan.However, Aughlisnafin would soon hit their opponents with a damaging blow as Tiernan Noadersquos high ball over the top found lsquoFin forward Adam Garland, who converted his sweetly struck shot into the top left corner for the second goal of the game after  minutes.Noade won a turnover from the resultant kick-out, but saw his effort sail wide before McGrattan replied with a point for Dundrum after winning an inidual battle with Aughlisnafin defender Sean Fitzsimmons.The contest was beginning to ebb and flow with both sets of supporters making their voices heard, as Garland dummied his man, but missed the target.Despite Noade pulling his shot wide a minute later, Aughlisnafinrsquos high balls over the top were clearly causing Dundrum all sorts of bother as their defence struggled to maintain the pressing forward line.Garland kicked over a free to give his side a - score line as Dundrum prepared to introduce substitute Odhran McKibbin to the pitch.Perhaps overeager to impress, McKibbin received a yellow card immediately following a late tackle, as referee Curran continued to show efficient officiating beyond his years.Soon after, McComiskey registered his third point of the match, but once again, Dundrum showed why they made it to the final.After overturning the ball in midfield, the ball worked its way to Dundrum captain Aidan Fegan, who played a lovely pass over the top to McGrattan.The forward found himself in acres of space and struck the ball with conviction past lsquoFin lsquokeeper Morgan Croskery and into the net.Garland replied with a free just before half time as the score read Aughlisnafin - Dundrum -.The lsquoFin began the quicker following the restart after a McComiskey lsquorsquo floated into Garland, who pointed over for the first score of the half.A series of wides took up the next five minutes of the game before McComiskey became the latest player to enter Conor Curranrsquos book, receiving a yellow for a high tackle.Travers then pulled his effort wide before his side won the resultant kick-out and forced a fantastic save from Dundrumrsquos Walsh, who stopped a certain goal.Walsh found himself at the opposite end of the pitch a minute later to kick over a fantastic free, which spurred team-mate Venney on to convert one himself in the following passage of play.This was Venneyrsquos third time raising the white flag and the last notable piece of action before the second water-break as Dundrum trailed by four.The last quarter was nothing short of dramatic, as both sets of players were clearly beginning to fatigue and yet still managed to throw everything at eachother.Dundrum really set the scene for a nail-biting last  minutes when they passed the ball neatly from one end of the pitch to the other before skipper Fegan found David McComiskey with only lsquokeeper Croskery to beat.Dundrumrsquos McComiskey duly converted make it a one-point game and now the atmosphere was beginning to reach fever pitch.John Hurley saw his chance sail wide for Dundrum before Garland kicked over a free to double his sidersquos lead.McGrattan continued to battle, winning a free out of nothing, before Walsh stepped up to send the ball over the bar.Shea Croskery received a yellow card in between two wide balls from Dundrum, as they resulted to kicking from range in the final five minutes.Walsh was forced to make another eye-catching save, this time preventing substitute Ruairi Croskery from converting.Garland managed to kick over a point a minute later to add to his impressive personal tally before Flanagan saw his long range effort split the posts to give Aughlisnafin a comfortable three point margin.With just seconds on the clock, Dundrum knew it was now or never and with the last free of the night attempted a short pass to allow an opportunity for a strike on goal.However, Shea Croskery was on hand to block the shot as Curranrsquos whistle sounded for the final time to signal it would be Dolen Croskeryrsquos men who would lt the trophy.Aughlisnafin: M Croskery J Matthews, S Fitzsimmons, S Willoughby O OrsquoToole, B McComiskey , N Travers D Steele , O FlanaganS Croskery , C Matthews, F Murphy C Croskery, A Garland , P OrsquoHare.Subs: C Rea, R Croskery, B Ogle, T Noade, J Murnin, R Murphy, O OrsquoNeil, D Murphy, D Tumelty, R Quinn, A Leneghan, B Willoughby, R Walsh.Yellow cards: N Travers, B McComiskey, S Croskery.Dundrum: K WalshR McGuigan, D Flaherty, C Miskelly, A Doyle, J Hurley, T McShane N Rogers, D McComiskeyP Curry, A Fegan , C Hogg, E King, M McGrattan , C Venney .Subs: C Coughlan, Oisin McKibbin, Odhran McKibbin, R Carey, D Brennan, G Grant, K Glavin, C Mulholland, S Keenan, D McComb, S Byrne, A Byrne, B OrsquoConnorYellow Cards: Odhran McKibbin.Referee: Conor Curran ..prettyPhoto

title: Brian gets on his bike to raise £3k
story: A PORTAFERRY man, who got on his bike for charity and cycled theof Ireland, has raised pound, for Marie Curie.Brian Doran mdash who is the Housing Executiversquos clerk of works for the southern region mdash cycled from Malin Head in Donegal to Mizen Head in Cork.Cycling across  miles of breathtaking Irish countryside, Brian was spurred on by the support he received from staff at the Housing Executiversquos Downpatrick office.He saw details of the charity cycle on social media and decided to ldquogo for it as he loved cycling.ldquoThe Executiversquos Downpatrick office really supported me with the fundraising effort and managed to raise over pound which was put towards my final amount, explained Brian. ldquoIrsquom really grateful for their contribution.Delighted to have raised pound,, Brian described the charity cycle ride as a ldquofantastic experience.He continued: ldquoI enjoyed every minute of it. I trained extensively and clocked up hundreds of practice miles in the weeks running up to the main event.Bronagh Magorrian, the housing organisationrsquos patch team leader for the Downpatrick area, said the local office was delighted to be able to support Brian.ldquoWe are really proud of Brian and what he has achieved and he worked really hard as part of this challenge, she said.ldquoBrian would be well-known in the Downpatrick office and is a popular staff member. We were more than happy to help him and donate towards such a worthy cause..prettyPhoto

title: Council debate on moves for green economy
story: ONE of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos most influential committees is to debate a proposal urging the organisation to match the income being achieved by the provincersquos other local authorities via the green economy.The motion by Downpatrick area councillor Cadogan Enright was due to be discussed at the councilrsquos monthly meeting last week, but was instead referred to the Strategy, Policy and Resources Committee.Ahead of the councilrsquos monthly meeting, members of Lecale Conservationrsquos Climate Action Youth Group staged a picket outside the local authorityrsquos Downshire Civic Centre headquarters in Downpatrick where council chairwoman, Cathy Mason, spoke with them.Cllr Mason was joined by Downpatrick area councillor Oonagh Hanlon, the current chair of the local authorityrsquos Finance Committee.Cllr Enright said ratepayers in Fermanagh pay poundm less in rates because their council ldquowelcomes the new green economy into the council area, arguing that renewable energy can brings jobs and new income sources into the Newry, Mourne and Down area.He claimed the leaders of the councilrsquos main parties do not have the vision to copy what is happening in Scotland, the Republic and even where in Northern Ireland.Cllr Enright described the new green economy as an ldquoengine for wealth and good jobs for rural councils in Northern Ireland,there is the courage to embrace it and provide a huge boost to the local farming and business community.He continued: ldquoSometimes it is called the lsquoelectried economyrsquo as it requires a massive reinforcing of the electricity grid to power all cars from . After this date, the grid will have to further expand to replace oil and gas heating with either electric-powered heat pumps or hydrogen from electrolysis of renewable energy.ldquoA huge programme of retrofitting homes will also have to be implemented during the next council area plan.ldquoAt the moment, despite my requests, this clear national policy is still not in the local councilrsquos proposed draft plan for . Even though renewables only account for % of energy consumed in Northern Ireland, they already produce three times more rates than fossil fuel plants and twice the number of jobs.Cllr Enright said his motion on making the most of the green economy can help save ratepayers money.He continued: ldquoIt is impossible to see how Newry Mourne and Down Council can hope to move to % renewable energy in line with national and international policies,it cannot even aspire to attracting a few renewable energy projects and jobs to our area.ldquoWhat I am proposing are low, easy to achieve targets for the  financial year of poundm per annum, followed by poundm a year in  and poundm annually by . Many councils in the Republic of Ireland have already passed the poundm mark like Donegal or Kerry, while Co Cork is fast approaching poundm per annum.Cllr Enright said the targets he is suggesting are easy to achieve and will deliver jobs for young people and help get the councilrsquos ldquofinancial donkey cart out of the rut of service cut-backs and allied rates hikes..prettyPhoto

title: Crossgar women’s walking group receives high vis bibs from Eurospar supermarket
story: A CROSSGAR womenrsquos walking group has been able to continue their adventures into the darker months thanks to a donation by the local Eurospar supermarket.Set up by community group Crossgar Le as the lockdown eased in May this year,  women have been gathering each week to pound the pavements, which has helped keep them social and active through tough times.The group has given participants the opportunity to get vital social interaction that was lost during lockdown, but in a safe and creative way. Now that the darker nights have come in, they have been given a donation of high visibility vests from Eurospar Crossgar, enabling them to continue their programme into the autumn winter months.Crossgar Le said the walking group has become so special to all involved.ldquoSo many women in the local area expressed an interest to meet each other and get active after the lockdowns were lted, a spokesperson said.ldquoWith the help of Walking for Health, an initiative from the local health trust, we have been able to set up a six-week programme, which comprises of five weeks of walking and one week where we all take part in a social activity.ldquoWe are now on our third set of walks since May and were worried about numbers ping due to the darker nights. Thankfully, Eurospar Crossgar has donated these fabulous vests which will make sure wersquore visible on our routes, but also gives us a sense of a team now that we have our own kit to wear.Nicola Tate, Eurospar Crossgar store manager, said: ldquoThe walking group has become an essential part of these local womenrsquos lives. Theyrsquove made great friends and have all benefited from it in some way, whether it be improved mood and reduced feelings of stress, or to gain fitness.ldquoWe are very proud to support this important local initiative and hope they gain more walkers as the weeks go by..prettyPhoto

title: Former church secretary Mary pens new book on history of Downpatrick graveyard
story: A NEW book which reveals some of the hidden history of a Downpatrick graveyard has just been published.The book, lsquoA Guide to the Notable Grave Inions the First Presbyterian ChurchDownpatrickrsquo, has been written by Mary Stewart, who recently stepped down as church secretary after  years.Mary has given a letime of service to the Stream Street church which is the oldest church in Downpatrick still in continuous use. It was opened in , although there was a previous church at Flying Horse, which was founded in .This latest book is a follow-up to her history of the church which was written in  to mark its th anniversary.She says the book serves two purposes mdash firstly, to act as a record of the inscriptions on the headstones, some of which are becoming badly eroded, and, secondly, to help the many visitors to the church who either come to find out information about their ancestors, or are interested in local history.There are  headstones in the graveyard, plus nine vaults or mausoleums and a number of unmarked graves.ldquoMany of the inscriptions related to people who were socially prominent, but some of them were being worn away and I thought it was time to record them all, Mary remarked. ldquoThe graveyard forms part of the social history of Downpatrick and it is important to preserve that history for the future.ldquoI think the book will also serve as a useful tool for people visiting the church. We get visitors from all over the world, including, America, Australia and England, who are trying to trace their family roots.A retired teacher mdash she was principal of Strand Primary School in east Belfast mdash Mary is devoted to her church. She is a church elder and was formerly the Sunday School teacher for  years.In  she received the British Empire Medal in the Queenrsquos Birthday Honours in recognition of her services to the community, which included her involvement in the Sunday School and the Girl Guide movement.She says she wrote the book ldquoto keep herself busy during the Covid lockdown. ldquoI was getting fed up and decided that writing a book would give me something to do. I have enjoyed writing it and I hope people will enjoy reading it.This is Maryrsquos sixth book to date. She has written three about her family, two about her church and a piece of fiction.In a foreword to the book, the Rev David Steers, church minister, commended Mary for her efforts.ldquoWe owe a great debt of thanks to Mary, who, as church secretary, has looked after the churchyard for  years and knows its secrets more than anyone , he said.ldquoWe are especially grateful to Mark for sharing the results of her research with us in this volume. It goes a long way towards illuminating the history and ethos of our Church and the place it has had in the local community throughout the centuries.Copies of the book are available at pound eachfrom the church, or by emailing Mary at marystewart@btinternet. Copies of her history of the church are also available at pound ..prettyPhoto

title: Former lawyer selected  by SDLP for Strangford
story: THE SDLP has selected a former prominent criminal lawyer as its candidate in Strangford ahead of next Mayrsquos Assembly election.Conor Houstonwill be hoping to secure one of the five seats up for grabs and go one better than the last Assembly election in  when the partyrsquos veteran politician Joe Boyle lost out to the DUPrsquos Peter Weir by just  votes.Mr Houston, who has acted in several high-profile criminal cases, said he was impressed by the SDLPrsquos efforts to ldquoreinvent itself and reach out to a range of erse voices under Colum Eastwoodrsquos leadership.Mr Houston said he wanted to be a new voice for Strangford.He continued: ldquoWe need a new vision in order to reach our potential. We need to see investment to revitalise our historic town centres, reduce chronic traffic congestion, tackle the climate crisis which threatens our way of le here and to facilitate jobs to make this area more than just a stop on the road to Belfast.ldquoOur towns and coastal communities have the opportunity to be at the forefront of the green jobs revolution, we have the people and the natural resources to become a huge success.Mr Houston said there is a need to see the Strangford area reach its tourism potential, as it has been Northern Irelandrsquos best kept secret for too long.ldquoItrsquos about time we chose people who have ambition to represent us, the Assembly candidate continued.ldquoFor  years wersquove been represented by the same political parties and Irsquove had enough of being let down by people and parties more interested in themselves than the needs of the people they represent.Mr Houston added: ldquoIrsquom calling on people to choose change and build a better le for everyone in Strangford and across Northern Ireland.ldquoThe SDLP candidate also paid tribute to Cllr Boyle and said he looked forward to working with him in the future.And as co-chair of One Young World Belfast , he will help bring , young people from across the globe to the city for the th anniversary of the Good Friday Agreement.Mr Houston is currently a director of Houston Solutions which provides bespoke strategic advice to government, businesses and the digitalentertainment industry. He is also a governor of thetrust and policy chair of the Federation of Small Businesses.SDLP leader Colum Eastwood said he was delighted that Mr Houston has been selected to run for the party in Strangford.ldquoConor brings with him a track record of delivery, innovative and bold ideas and a willingness to work hard to get the job done, he said.ldquoI know Conor has not taken the decision to enter the political arena lightly. Throughout his successful career in the private sector he has seen first hand how the current system is letting our people down. His track record in standing up for the people who need it most compelled him to do what he can to make a dference.Mr Eastwood said like many, the partyrsquos Strangford candidate ldquois fed up of the status quo and has put himself forward to do something about it.The party leader added: ldquoThe SDLP knows that we need change so that we can cut our waiting lists for housing and healthcare, reform our broken education system and intervene on the climate crisis.ldquoTo achieve all these things, we need people like Conor fighting for people in a strong SDLP team in the Assembly..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  November 14%2C 2001
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash Downpatrick is in line for a major shopping boost from leading High Street retailers, Top Shop and Dorothy Perkins.The county town is to feature heavily in a signicant financial investment by the Arcadia Group, which will see new branches of the stores opening at the start of the new year.A number of new jobs are to be created as a result of the move by the fashion retailers which are to open for business at The Grove shopping centre in Lower Market Street.The Arcadia Group, which owns both retailers, has signed leases for two , sq ft units at the complex.It is the first time a multi-national fashion retailer has invested in Downpatrick and it is hoped the new stores will encourage other firms to open shops in the town.Agents handling the lease of the units at the Downpatrick centre say the move by Top Shop and Dorothy Perkins ldquoclearly demonstrates their business confidence in the town.A spokesman for McKibbin Commercial property consultants said the Grove Centre occupied a prime location in the heart of the town.Mr Michael Fitzell said with other major stores including NPO, Boots, Peacocks, Xtravision and Lidl close by, the new stores will be in good company.Flagging up the St Patrick Centre and recently completed Millennium Square Mr Fitzell said McKibbin Commercial had been arguing the potential of the town to major retailers for some time.SAUL mdash Children in the Saul and Raholp areas will soon have a new playground. Work started last week on the new facility which is being provided at the grounds of the local gaelic club.The scheme is a joint initiative by the Saul club and Down Council and work is expected to be completed within the new few weeks.The arrival of the contractors on site late Thursday morning marked the end of a long campaign by local councillor Mr Peter Craig.He is delighted work is underway and has no doubt the playground will make a major contribution to the lives of young people in the area.He said the gaelic clubrsquos premises are being used to house the playground because no other suitable sites could be identied in the area.And in a bid to further improve safety standards, Roads Service officials are to provide new lighting along a footpath which runs from Raholp to the GAA pitch.BALLYNAHINCH mdashA senior police officer has rejected claims from a Sinn Fein councillor that a police car sped away from a Catholic couple who had been attacked in Ballynahinch at the weekend.Inspector Paul McClean has refuted Francis Brannfrsquos allegations that police allowed the assailants to escape after attacking the couple in fast food premises at High Street in the early hours of Sunday.Inspector McClean has also rejected Cllr Brannfrsquos allegations that the injured couple were questioned by an officer from a mobile support unit while their attackers were ldquoallowed to escape.Alleging that the Catholic couple were ldquoviciously beaten, Mr Brannf said that after being head butted and ldquobeaten to the ground the woman ran to a nearby police car to get help while her husband was being assaulted.He also said police allowed ldquothe Loyalists to escape the scene of yet another sectarian attack on nationalists in Ballynahinch.NEWCASTLE mdash Two Stormont departments are at loggerheads after Newcastle beach failed a series of water quality tests.Department of the Environment experts failed Newcastle beach because the level of sewage contamination found in the bathing waters was a breach of European guidelines.But the Department of Regional Development, responsible for sewage treatment, has rejected the DoErsquos reasons, claiming other factors are to blame.Only three out of  Northern Ireland beaches failed the quality tests which must be passedbeaches are to be considered for the prestigious Blue Flag quality award. Tyrella passed the stringent tests for the seventh successive year.Announcing the disappointing news for Newcastle, Environment Minister, Sam Foster, said the failure of the three beaches was due to sewage dischargers, which he added highlights the problems caused by the lack of investment in sewerage services.However, the Water Service yesterday stressed that it was unlikely the discovery was due to the failure of the multi-million pound sewage treatment plant which was built at the townrsquos harbour in the s.A Water Service spokesman said there has been no failure at the sewage plant since  and it is therefore questionable that it is the source of the problem.KILLYLEAGH mdash Killyleagh Development Association will be unveiling its latest regeneration scheme at the end of the month.The official ceremony will be performed by former Down councillor, Mr Sam Osborne, who will be joined by a number of people from the town and representatives from the International Fund for Ireland.Work on the High Street project started in January and was completed in September and has transformed the area, with the ambitious pound, project including four ground floor shops, two first floor apartments and a cottage.The cottage has recently been sold and the four retail units are currently available for rental with Association officials confident they can secure tenants.Construction work began at the start of the year and the project team behind the scheme are confident the scheme will greatly enhance this area of Killyleagh which is close to the townrsquos historic castle.CASTLWELLAN mdash Elderly people in Castlwellan are being disturbed by children running through their gardens, according to the local SDLP branch.During a recent meeting of the Castlewellan and Kilcoo branch, the chairman, John Duggan, said he was concerned that some older residents were being bothered by a number of young people.Mr Duggan pointed out that Castlewellan was an excellent place to live but said there was an absolute need for children to pay courtesy to their elders within the neighbourhood.ldquoWhat makes a good community spirit is the ability to have respect for others within the community. There have been some episodes recently where children have been running through gardens and hedges at homes of elderly people.ldquoI would ask them to give these members of the community the peace and space they deserve and consider their feelings in pursuit of fun, he said.BALLYKINLAR mdash Ballykinlar cross-community playgroup has been strongly praised by education inspectors for providing a positive ethos which promotes childrenrsquos confidence and self-esteem.The Department of Education report lists a number of strengths of the playgroup which operates out of the old school on the Carricknab Road.Staff are headily praised for their leadership and dedication to the children and the inspectors found there were only a few areas which need attention.ldquoThe staff treat the children with care and respect and provide a secure, supportive environment which helps the children grow in confidence and independence, said the report.SAINTFIELD mdash The achievements and success of the younger pupils at Saintfield High School were cerebrated during a special junior school prize day last week.The principal, Mr Robert Miss, said the school prided itself on being a family school offering support, interest and encouragement in all the pupils strive to achieve.Mr Mills proudly pointed out that the schoolrsquos well established year eight induction programme seeks to ensure that all new pupils entering Saintfield High School settle quickly into their new environment..prettyPhoto

title: Green light for St Patrick’s Day
story: A ST Patrickrsquos Day parade in Downpatrick is scheduled to go ahead next year.The Recorder can confirm that Newry, Mourne and Down Council is pressing ahead with plans for the event which regularly attracts thousands of visitors to the town.The cross-community spectacular was last held in , with last yearrsquos event one of the districtrsquos first high profile casualties of the emerging coronavirus pandemic.The parade was cancelled due to lockdown restrictions to help prevent the spread of the deadly virus, but council officials are confident the event can go ahead next March.With Covid restrictions now eased, they are keen to see the  parade take place with details surprisingly unveiled to councillors in private during Mondayrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee.As the public health emergency has eased slightly, a number of councillors believe that as the parade is an outdoor event, it will be able to proceed, provided people continue to exercise caution.Downpatrick area councillor, Dermot Curran, said while there are over four months to go before the parade would be held, ious plans have to be put in place.He said decisions have to be taken now to ensure that all the pieces in the eventrsquos jigsaw are in place and believes that the current environment allows for the popular event to proceed.ldquoPublic health advice rightly prompted the decision to cancel the last two St Patrickrsquos Day parades but the situation has changed. The fact that this will be an outdoor event is also an important factor in deciding that it can proceed, Cllr Curran continued.ldquoThe virus is still in circulation, but a signicant number of people have been vaccinated and things are certainly a lot dferent compared to last year. Protecting peoplersquos health remains important and we should all continue to wear a mask when required to do, exercise good hand hygiene and maintain our distance from others.Cllr Curran said the past  months had been some of the most dficult people across the district haf ever faced, suggesting news that the St Patrickrsquos Day is due to proceed will provide them with a glimmer of hope for the future.ldquoThere have been many large outdoor events over recent months and normality is slowly to starting to , but there is no room for complacency and we must all continue adhering to the public safety message, he continued.ldquoThe St Patrickrsquos Day parade in Downpatrick is hugely popular and people who regularly attend it now have something to look forward to. Normality is slowly ing and I and others hope that we can celebrate next yearrsquos event in style.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council spokesman confirmed that plans are being drawn up to hold a St Patrickrsquos Day parade in Downpatrick next year..prettyPhoto

title: Locals for Ballyclare
story: WITH the wave of enthusiasm both before and after the Bobby Rea cross country a few weeks back, it was no surprise that East Down AC had a healthy number of runners eager to get back out on the grass for another race.This time it was off to Six Mile Water Park in Ballyclare for the McConnell Shield cross country event hosted by East Antrim Harriers.As per the norm the ladies went first and as usual they ran a shorter distance than the men.This is a matter of hot debate at the highest level as to whether it should be one distance for all genders but at grass roots, I suspect most females are secretly smug that they can get away with a lap or two fewer.The course at Ballyclare is quite accessible to all as it is not that hilly, in fact it is flat apart from a sharp rise at one end of the loop.It is also not that technical so while this could be seen as an easy run, it just means that the pace is quicker overall. Catherine OrsquoConnor was in fineform and led the EDAC ladies in style.Her aim was top ten and she managed that with ease coming eighth in . for the three miles. She also got the prize for first over  as a further boost to her confidence.Leanne Spick, who has only recently joined the club, is a competent runner and game for anything so, new spikes purchased, she turned up to see what was what.She was second EDAC lady home, th overall in .. It is fair to say she looked right at home and will likely make further improvement now that she knows the drill.Nuala Taylor, coaxed into racing by her husband John, who wanted her to know how much he had suffered at Comber, couldnrsquot see what the fuss was about as she flew round in . .Wayne Giles gets a bit of teasing for being in the ladiesrsquo race due to being over  but he takes it in good part.He has even volunteered to shave his legs to help him blend in for the team photo. He was th overall .Maureen Kelly was full of beans and went off like the clappers but soon realised that she would be better setting her own pace rather than getting sucked into the speed of others.She sensibly slowed and found a more sustainable rhythm completing in . in nd place.Janine Murray has been running well but with a heavy cold and a hamstring niggle, this is one race she is happy to have behind her. She placed st in ..Alison Carroll in contrast said that this was possibly her most enjoyable cross country race ever and she was well pleased with her time of ..Sam Anderson, going from marathon distance to this shorter effort, was afraid of being last but she was far from it and has even signed up for the next event in two weeks time. Her time of . earned her th slot.With the ladies done and dusted, the men swarmed to the start area. There were nine EDAC representatives, a mix of the experienced and the first timers ready for the five laprace.Gordy Graham prefers the feel of tarmac when he is racing, but he aways commits to whatever challenge is set before him. He, like Catherine, was aiming for a top ten and by virtue of targeting runners ahead hemanoeuvred himself into a good position but had to sprintright to the line to hold his tenth place.He recorded . which is speedy for an off road run.Mackenzie Murray is  but with no junior category for this age, he decided to join in the menrsquos senior team and he proved a useful addition.He found the distance long and at one stage was doubting his ability to stay with the pace but he hung in and even passed more runners to finish th overall in a time of ..Martin Willcox loves cross country, as does Dee Murray, and as old hands they know that pacing is key.They went lap after lap, never showing the strain and finishing in . and . respectively, th and nd.Right behind Dee was Jonny Holmes. This week he was notied that he has been selected as reserve for the over  NI team in the North South Masters XC Challenge to be held this weekend in Belfast, so this was a good chance for some last minute practice.He ran strongly finishing rd in . and we wish him well for Saturday. Carl Keenan, after spectating at Comber, thought that he might enjoy trying cross country for a change and he was right.Carl loved the feel of the grass beneath his feet as well as being part of the EDAC team and ran a steady race coming th in ..Eamon Kelly, who said he wouldnrsquot be back after Comber, had a change of heart as did John Taylor.It looked like these two plus Patrick Smith were having a ball judging by the smiles as they passed or perhaps we misinterpreted their grimaces.Spurred on by the shouts of club mates, they battled to the end and all three made the top . Eamon was th , John thand Patrick th in ..With banana bread and chocolate on hand to revive them, the mood at the finish line was buoyant and the whole EDAC contingent went home satisfied with having made good use of the day.The Born  Run team are excited to be back in business after the long layoff during the pandemic.They welcomed back the runners with open arms to the first event of six in the lsquoWinter Run Forest Runrsquo series, namely the Minnowburn K and K. Both distances started at the Mary Peters Track and then headed off into the forest and then along the towpath.There were over  in the K and  in the K. East Down had two runners both doing the K, Sharon Madine and Rachel Madine .Despite her birthday celebrations the night before, Sharon looked fresh as she set off with the lead pack and she was more than able to stick with the pace throughout.While she didnrsquot particularly relish the hill at the start or the climb to the finish, she appreciated the scenery en route.Her efforts placed her third female at the finish and it is worth noting that her time of . was only a few seconds off second place.Rachel equally enjoyed both the route and the race and was pleased to come well up the field in nd place .For Rachel though, this was only part one of her weekend commitments.The annual event organised by Atlas Running on behalf of the Ballynahinch British Legion took place on Sunday morning with a K route along the back roads of the town.Even though she had already raced the day before, Rachel Madine felt that she couldnrsquot let this race go by without taking part as it is right on her doorstep.In fact she could be considered a regular as this is her third time enteringThe  odd runners who turned up were delighted to be greeted with pleasant, bright weather as last year they had to endure torrential rain and high winds.Despite the hilly course, the race was won in a speedy . by Lawrence OrsquoHara of North Belfast. Rachel finished th in a time of .. A good weekendrsquos work for her.It was cross country all the way for the EDAC juniors last weekend but one option was closer to home in Ballyclare while the other necessitated a long drive to Donegal.The home birds were running in the U- race prior to the McConnell Shield cross country in the Six Mile Water Park. It may only have been a mile but it was a tough mile.Matthew Taylor actually ran more than a mile as he arrived late thinking he was in the next race on the program and performed the quickest vest change and number putting on ever seen.He just made it to the back of the pack as the whistle blew. Undeterred he dug in and made his way through the small pack and was barely in his stride when he realised that it was time to sprint for the finish line.He couldnrsquot believe his luck when he was then handed a medal for second boy. Talk about a whirlwind experience - maybe the lack of time to consider what lay ahead was a good thing.Even though he had no time to greet them at the start, he was able to congratulate the two other EDAC runners at the end.Amelia Spick was taking on her first cross country ever and seemed to enjoy the race. Her new spikes are now duly christened and hopefully she willfor another shot at this discipline.She ran an even pace as advised and finished sixth girl and ninth overall. Ky Murray was two places behind and closing in the latter stages.Her lightning sprint brought her within five seconds of Amelia and she was placed eighth girl overall.The juniors then took on the role of supporters, cheering on the adults which was much appreciated encouragement. It is this element of whole club camaraderie that makes cross country so special.Further afield then were the Robinson brothers who had travelled to Stranorlar in Donegal for the NI and Ulster XC Championships .Despite some rain early on in Ballyclare, the athletes raced in dry, almost sunny conditions and there was very little mud to slow them down, but Oliver and Alex were not so lucky.The rain the night before made the course very boggy and although the rainbows on the day suggested it might clear, this was just a tease. Even during the dry spells the biting wind made conditions tough for the runners.Alex was first up running a distance of two kilometres in the U- race. He started safely and quickly became part of the leading pack on the course two loops around two fields.On the second lap he led the breakaway pack and looked comfortable as they disappeared into the second field.When he emerged he had ped to fth and was running with just one shoe having lost the other in the deep mud. The last m metres were heroic as he battled to hold his place only being overtaken in the last m.He was so disappointed with the outcome and on reflection said he should have ditched his shoe sooner instead of losing speed trying to keep it on.A hard lesson to learn but Alex showed his grit and has been rewarded with selection as an inidual into the U- Ulster and NI team for the All-Irelands in Gowran, Kilkenny at the start of December.He was placed sixth out of  runners in a time of ., only  seconds behind the winner. The wayward shoe was retrieved from the mud later.His brother Ollie was in two minds whether to run at all. He was nursing an injury acquired at rugby but he showed commitment by putting his vest on to line up for the U- four-and-a-half kilometre race.He knew he wasnrsquot at his best but didnrsquot want to withdraw without giving it a shot. He went out steadily, wisely treating it as a training run, but still finishing rd out of the field of  runners.When the times are analysed he may well end up at the All-Irelands as part of the county team. Either way, he did the club proud and both boys are to be congratulated on their efforts..prettyPhoto

title: Make the Call helps families with £5m aid
story: NEW figures have revealed that over , people across the Newry Mourne and Down area claimed almost poundm in unclaimed benefits last year.The cash was paid under the lsquomake the callrsquo scheme spearheaded by the Department for Communities.The government department said figures for the last financial year reveal that people who used the service became pound better off per week on average, with almost , accessing almost poundm in unclaimed benefits province-wide.The lsquomake the callrsquo service supports people in accessing benefits, services and supports to which they are entitled, but have not been claiming.A total of  people in Newry Mourne and Down claimed pound,, last year.Stormont communities minister, Deirdre Hargey, said her departmentrsquos scheme has helped people who lsquomade the callrsquo become, on average, pound. better off per week.ldquoDuring  , we received over  referrals from our partner organisations which helped ensure people are receiving their full entitlement to benefits, supports and services that can make a real dference to their lives, she explained.ldquoOften people donrsquot realise there is support out there to assist them during dficult times. With lsquoMake the Callrsquo we are actively reaching out to those thousands of people who find themselves in situations where every pound generated, and every assistance offered, can help improve lives.The Make the Call Wraparound Service works in conjunction with a range of partner organisations such as the Housing Executive, Housing Rights, Dementia NI and Carers NI.Additional supports available can include blue badges for car parking or free bus passes, access to local groups to help maintain community connections and social independence, help with health costs, home safety checks and assistance with reducing energy costs.Ms Hargey added: ldquoThe aim of lsquomake the callrsquo is to support people when they need it most, some of whom are vulnerable through age, disability, illness or adverse circumstances.ldquoAs well as providing advice on the financial support that may be available, it also connects people with other services and supports across the wider government, voluntary and community sectors.For more information telephone   , text ADVICE to , visit nidirect.gov.uk makethecall or email makethecall@dfcni.gov.uk.prettyPhoto

title: Minister blasted on ‘dire condition’ of rural roads
story: STORMONT roads minister Nichola Mallon has rejected claims that she and the Department for Infrastructure have failed to address a ldquogrowing crisis across rural communities in the district in relation to roads maintenance and investment.The criticism has been levelled by Slieve Croob councillor Cathy Mason who said the minister at the helm of the government department has not responded to issues raised by her and her Sinn Fein colleagues locally.Branding the inaction as ldquosimply not good enough, Cllr Mason said rural communities deserve better and that rural roads locally are in a ldquodire condition.She continued: ldquoLarge potholes are scattered throughout the area and roadside grass cutting has been neglected, leaving the roads dangerous for road users, but this is only the tip of the iceberg.Cllr Mason claimed Mrs Mallonrsquos ldquofailing goes well beyond potholes and patch work repairs and that despite possessing the biggest capital budget, she continues to stall delivery of much-needed resurfacing schemes including one in Loughinisland and the proposed Ballynahinch bypass.ldquoThis is costing our rural communities and although I recognise there has been an ongoing legal issue regarding these resurfacing works, we have not yet seen the Minister take any action to resolve the matters.ldquoMinister Mallon appears happy enough to shelve these important projects rather than take responsibility to find solutions and deliver for our rural communities.ldquoThe Ballynahinch bypass plans are in place and ready to be signed off on, but Minister Mallon is sitting on her hands, depriving the local community of this transformative scheme. Enough is enough, it is time to see these projects delivered to improve the lives of local workers and families.With the approach of winter and worsening road conditions due to weather and darker evenings, Cllr Mason said visibility will become poorer.ldquoWe need to see urgent action from the Minister to address the concerns of the local community to ensure our roads are safe and up to satisfactory standard before winter hits, she contended.ldquoWinter gritting is a huge cause for concern for many in our local rural communities and the Minister needs to deliver a more effective solution to winter gritting on our rural roads with priority for those in more isolated areas who fear another winter stuck in their homes, the councillor continued.ldquoMany farmers who rely on milk collection lorries arriving daily and accessing feed supplies for their animals, need the certainty that their services and routine will not be disrupted. Those who work as frontline staff such as the emergency services and domiciliary care workers must have a safe passage to and from peoplersquos homes, while childcare services and rural schools must be able to operate smoothly.ldquoWe cannot allow ordinary people to suffer and a management plan must be implemented to ensure gritting is carried out throughout the winter period, she added, confirming that she has written to Mrs Mallon to raise her concerns.A DfI spokesman said Mrs Mallon ldquocompletely rejects these unfounded assertions and will continue to work equitably across all council areas, including South Down, to improve the condition of the road network.ldquoThe Minister is fully aware of the condition of roads in South Down and will continue to work for all communities to deliver the infrastructure they need, he said.ldquoThe fact that the Minister has increased the funding for the rural roads fund by % and allocated poundm mdash a % increase on last yearrsquos budget mdash specically for rural roads across the North, including South Down, is a clear demonstration of this commitment to rural communities. This funding is not impacted by current legal challenges.The spokesman explained that as a result of challenges to awarding resurfacing contracts earlier this year, ious schemes which the Department had intended to progress during the current financial year have been delayed in four council areas, including Newry Mourne and Down.But he confirmed the Department is taking forward a new procurement strategy and hopes to be in position to go to tender shortly and to have new term contracts in place next January to continue resurfacing programmes in these areas, including in South Down.ldquoSignicant programmes of work have been delivered across all areas in  , in particular on rural roads and while capacity to reallocate resurfacing budgets across areas is limited, every effort is being made to maximise spend across all areas, said the spokesman.ldquoIn relation to the Ballynahinch bypass, Minister Mallon provided an opening allocation of pound.m for land costs and scheme development in -. The next steps are procurement and progression to construction.ldquoProgression to construction will, however, depend on budget allocations made to the Department in future years. Subject to funding being made available, it is estimated that it would take around  months to the start of construction from any decision to move to procurement, and a further  months to construct the scheme.The spokesman explained that as part of planning for the winter gritting programme, the Department ensures that adequate staff are available, all winter service equipment is in satisfactory working order and that there are adequate supplies of salt.He added: ldquoWhile the Department generally salts the main through routes which carry more than , vehicles per day, in exceptional circumstances, roads with dficult topography carrying between , and , vehicles daily will also be salted.ldquoGrit piles are also available for use by the public on a self-help basis on selected routes not included on the salting schedule and arrangements are in place to enlist the help of private contractors and local farmers to assist in efforts to clear blocked roads in rural areas..prettyPhoto

title: Multi agency  response call on foul smell
story: A LOCAL politician has called for a multi-agency response to two issues of concern in the Dundrum area.Northern Ireland Water, the Department for Infrastructure and Rivers Agency have been asked to address recent damage caused by flood water at the Moneycarragh River, with the utility company and Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos environmental health department asked to investigate the cause of foul smelling liquid seeping from land close to Dam Lane in the village.The appeal for the ious agencies to work together on both issues has been made by Slieve Croob councillor Alan Lewis.In relation to the Moneycarragh River, the councillor has called for the waterway to be ldquoed to its natural state, with the appeal coming after recent flooding which led to a burst pipe resulting in a number of consumers in the area left without supply.In June, Cllr Lewis raised concerns of local farmers with NI Water after a concrete floor was installed on the floor of the river, directly under Bennettrsquos bridge which runs over it.ldquoThe work prevented water from pooling, which subsequently forced floodwater to erode stone walls and the river bank which exposed a water supply the pipe which was damaged by rocks and it burst, he added.Cllr Lewis claimed rising floodwater has also undermined the integrity of the bridge and widened the river banks which exposed the water supply pipe.ldquoPreviously, farmers were able to drive machinery down the natural land slope to collect water from the river for animals and farm use, but this access has been altered so much that a sizeable dip has been left on the river bank.Cllr Lewis said the damage was ldquopredictable and claimed that the manipulation of the riverrsquos natural flow has, over time, distorted its integrity, warning that erosion which will eventually cause the collapse of the supporting walls at the bridge and adjoining roadway.He has asked NI Water and roads officials to urgently join forces to address the issue andthe river bed to its natural state.Turning to Dam Lane, Cllr Lewis says he hopes local afgghghuthority environmental health officials and NI Water will be able to address the issue.ldquoI recently received numerous complaints regarding a foul smelling fluid which has been seeping onto the pavement at this part of the village. There are suggestions that fluid is coming from a nearby drain or sewer, he explained.Cllr Lewis said that while he is aware that there is a sewage treatment plant nearby, there are no suggestions that the spillage came from it.He added: ldquoIt is in everyonersquos interest to identy what is casing this issue and to recty it as soon as possible..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle woman Kathy to meet Sir David Attenborough at event
story: A NEWCASTLE woman will be rubbing shoulders with Sir David Attenborough at a virtual event which will explore ways of ensuring a better future.Kathy Black is taking part in the Festival of Discovery, which begins tomorrow and ends on Saturday.Also joining her in the event, which is being run by the Eden Project, will be comedian John Bishop, best-selling author Ben Miller and BBC gardening presenter Mark Lane.Al of them will be taking part in inspiring sessions about eco-friendly initiatives taking place across the UK.Kathy, who runs Unit T in Newcastle, will be sharing the story of how she and a team of volunteers responded to their local arearsquos needs by opening a sustainable community kitchen during the pandemic.Built from re-purposed materials and located in the heart of the town, Unit T distributes home-grown produce, local goods and food near its sell-by date.As well as providing a vital and sustainable service for the community, Unit T have inspired and involved young people to live within their means and connect with each other and the natural world.The three-day Festival of Discovery is jam-packed with speakers,  and workshops.Tracey Robbins, Head of UK Delivery at Eden Project Communities, said: ldquoWersquore absolutely thrilled to be inviting Kathy to the Festival of Discovery.ldquoHere at Eden Project Communities, we know that there are thousands of amazing people doing their bit to protect the planet by joining forces with their communities and seeing the amazing things that can happen when we work together.ldquoWe canrsquot wait to hear some of their stories and hope that everyone attending will come away feeling inspired and motivated to get together to protect our planet.The Festival of Discovery will take place online. Sessions are free and open to anyone via www.thefestivalofdiscovery..prettyPhoto

title: Spring date for Down High School contract is possible
story: THE contract to build Down High Schoolrsquos new multi-million pound campus could be awarded as early as next spring.The Education Authority has confirmed this week that tenders to build the new school on land behind Down Councilrsquos former Strangford Road headquarters in Downpatrick were issued last month.Education officials expect that it will take  months to build the eagerly-anticipated new building and complete all associated site works once construction work on the ultra-modern school gets underway.The proposed development site was purchased some time ago by the Department of Education with the construction of the new school deemed a priority as far back as  due to what at the time was described as the existing schoolrsquos ldquosubstandard accommodation and over-reliance on temporary classrooms at its Mount Crescent site.The site of the new campus mdash which borders the Strangford and Quoile roads mdash is located in an area of outstanding natural beauty which also includes a graveyard linked to the townrsquos former workhouse.Extensive archaeological work was disrupted by the coronavirus but has resumed to identy and evaluate any remains at the site.It is understood that any which are discovered will be relocated to a nearby site during an ecumenical service led by local clergy.School officials say they are aware of the ldquohistoric signicance of the development site, with plans to commemorate important parts of local history.Last week, a planning application was submitted to request a iation to a condition on the original planning approval for the new school.The iation is to change the wording of the archaeological condition to allow the development of the new school to commence once Newry, Mourne and Down Council has approved an archaeological plan of works, rather than on the implementation of the planned work.An Education Authority spokesperson explained that this is to allow construction of the new school to start, in tandem with the completion of the archaeological works which, due to the signicant findings, could take some time.ldquoSite works are due to finish next January. However the report could take a further six months or more to complete, the spokesperson confirmed.Education officials have also revealed that an addendum to the original business case was completed and approved in March this year.They say the new school project was issued for tender in October with a target of contract award by the second quarter of  ldquoto complete a -month contract period for construction of the new school building and associated works..prettyPhoto

title: Tollymore United’s Stormort and Soccer Splits talk looks back on events surrounding partition
story: A LOCAL soccer clubrsquos history project marking the th anniversary of the founding of Northern Ireland is nearing its completion.The final talk in Tollymore Unitedrsquos very successful lsquoStormont and Soccer Splitsrsquo project takes place tomorrow evening at .pm at Greenhill YMCArsquos Community Hub.The talk will be delivered by leading historian Dr Cormac Moore and will be streamed live on https:vimeo event  ffdb.Dr Moore will discuss the day-to-day effect of partition on business, unions, the law, religion, education, sport road and rail links.Of particular interest will be the Belfast trade boycott which was ordered by Daacuteil Eacuteireann.The Stormont and Soccer Splits project is funded by the Northern Ireland Officersquos Shared History Fund, administered by the National Lottery Heritage Fund. The project is one of  projects funded through the Shared History Fund, which supports groups to mark the centenary in a thoughtful, inclusive and engaging way.The first part of the project took place in July and was a talk on the events leading up to the partition of Ireland delivered by Dr Moore. It can be viewed at the following link: https:player.vimeo video .This was followed in September by a talk on the Irish soccer split, also delivered by Dr Moore. The discussion told the story of why Southern clubs broke away from the Irish Football Association in  and can be viewed on https:vimeo event  embed eae.The third part of the project took place on Friday, October , and featured a re-enactment of an international game between Ireland and England that took place in Belfast exactly  years earlier. The match was attended by Northern Ireland Secretary of State Brandon Lewis.Tomorrowrsquos event concludes the project with the online talks being very well received with over  people viewing them to date.Tollymore chairman Adrian Howard said: ldquoWe are really pleased to have delivered this project. It has been a lot of fun and very informative with a history teacher who I know telling me how useful it was for his lower sixth class.ldquoIt has certainly been very informative but a lot of hard work. On behalf of the club I would like to thank the Heritage Lottery Fund for all their support in helping us to deliver this project and everyone  that has helped us in any way.Dr Moore, who is delivering the talks, is a historian with Dublin City Council and is helping to deliver their Decade of Commemorations programme..prettyPhoto

title: Twinning group enjoys Ring of Gullion tour
story: MEMBERS of the Rowallane and Slieve Croob Community Twinning Group recently organised a guided coach tour which took in the most impressive sights and monuments of the Ring of Gullion.Guide Una Walsh, who is passionate about the townlands and knows them all theand breadth of South Armagh, accompanied members on their journey through the breathtaking landscape, whilst enlightening them about the rich natural, built, archaeological and cultural heritage, oral tradition, and the many myths and legends from Cuchulainn to Finn McCool.Visit highlights included stops at Creggan Parish Church and graveyard, the Crooked Lake in Camlough, Killeavy old churches, Bessbrook model village and Quaker settlement.Twinning group members also stopped off at Derrymore House, an elegant, thatched manor house dating back to , situated in a partly-walled demesne with scenic walks and beautul woodland, managed by the National Trust. A delicious picnic lunch was prepared on the morning of the tour by Diane at On a Roll in Castlewellan and enjoyed by the group in the Mullaghbawn Community Centre.The local cross-community group, which comprises mainly retired people from every background, enjoyed their recent outing thanks to the enthusiasm and expertise of their expert guide, with the group also extending its thanks to James from Ballyred Coaches.The twinning group would like to thank Una Walsh for a ldquowonderful day with the group also thankful to its esteemed local historian, Horace Reid, who provided research into Derrymore House for the visit and to Newry Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Good Relations Programme for its generous funding which made this cross-community coach trip possible..prettyPhoto

title: ben lowry essays in  about northern ireland on its  centenary foresaw province staying in uk but did not foresee change from within
story: Anniversary of Rev Robert Bradford and Kenneth Campbell murders: ‘IRA’s brutal crimes can’t be whitewashed’   TUV: Protocol dismantling the Union before our eyesNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionBen Lowry: Essays in  about Northern Ireland on its  centenary foresaw province staying in UK but did not foresee change from withinIn summer , this newspaper ran  essays called Union , in which pro Union contributors were asked to look a decade ahead and envisage Northern Ireland on its centenary.By Ben LowrySaturday, th November , : amUpdated Saturday, th November , : am  "       "  Writers in  thought the Union would be safe in  but didn’t consider it might be only technically so. What does it matterthe Union is secureconcessions to Irish nationalism are so wide-ranging that Northern Ireland is utterly unlike any other part of UK Would it still be part of the UK  etcIt was a fascinating series. By August I was struck by the confidence of essay writers that NI would still be in UK in . They were right. But no-one addressed the possibility of NI being technically in the Union, but so changed as to be halfway to an all-Ireland. I penned the below essay to suggest that coming contributors address that. But I was uneasy expressing a view as then news editor . I was also wary about contradicting the essay writers. After consulting senior colleagues I agreed not to publish it. I do so now because it is  and concerns I raised have even greater relevance now than then. Beneath the article I have add updated thoughts on my points below.THE Union is secure, and will be in , many of our contributors have told us.In the News Letter’s Union  series so far there has been large agreement that the British link will survive past Northern Ireland’s th anniversary.But what does it mean to say that the Union is secure, or indeed what does it matter Those are follow-on questions that have not been so widely considered.What does it matter that the Union has been securedthe concessions to Irish nationalism are so comprehensive and wide-ranging that Northern Ireland in fact looks utterly unlike any other part of the kingdom Some of the following scenarios may seem provocative, but take a moment to imagine them: • A Northern Ireland in which you need a passport to get to Great Britain• A Northern Ireland teeming with powerful enforcers who see discrimination and sectarianism behind all sorts of human failings• A Northern Ireland which is, in terms of its very identity, an enlarged Stroke City, in which the media alternate between using its name Northern Ireland and other labels that deny its existence, such as the north of Ireland• A Northern Ireland that has fiscal powers that remove its economy yet further from the British mainstream• A Northern Ireland in which BBC Radio Ulster is broadcast in gaelic night after night, so that the overwhelming majority of the station’s listeners are unable to understand it during much of evening primetime• A Northern Ireland in which all road signs are jointly in gaelic • A Northern Ireland which toleration of violence in the name of human rights is pushed to the very extremes, providing it is aimed against agents of the state. In which calculated attacks on police, risking paralysis or death, are accepted in preference to a police response involving real force• A Northern Ireland which has a Bill of Rights that includes socio and economic rights, like something out of the old communist Eastern bloc• A Northern Ireland in which there is a growing consensusthat the earlier NI was a failed state• A Northern Ireland in which that coalition agrees that there was widespread collusion – facilitating wholesale murder – between loyalist killers the RUC and British Army • A Northern Ireland in which such assumptions about an entirely malign British form the basis on which the past, or any allegiance to it, is investigated or treated• A Northern Ireland in which those who planned massacres against civilians are not only treated as equals with the British forces, but are able to demand full accountability of those state forces while shamelessly covering up their own history• A Northern Ireland in which the Republic’s president can come and go freely, presiding over official s – a presidency that appears to allow its office-holder to cite political preconditions before the apolitical British head of state can set foot in the Republic [this was before the royal visit of ]• A Northern Ireland in which the Republic’s government can be a partisan player, while demanding neutrality on the part of those who actually have sovereignty• A Northern Ireland which must, necessarily must, include in government a party that the Republic will not tolerate in its own halls of powerTo be clear, imagining these ious scenarios does not mean they likely: as our recent story [published in ] on Northern Irishness pointed out, a large minority of Catholics accept the title and the state.And the Human Rights Commission’s Bill of Rights proposals have been comprehensively rejected by the main GB parties, and received coolly even in the Republic.Further, the Tories under David Cameron have sent out clear “hold on a minute” signals to any assumptions that they must be impartial on matters such as the future of the Union.Meanwhile, there is no suggestion that Northern Ireland will ever lose its Westminster MPs and many unionists, indeed Orangemen, will point to a real change in how they are received south of the border.So it is extreme to assume that all of the scenarios listed above will come to pass. Yet all the scenarios, and more, are at least conceivable within the Union.Some are not hypotheses but the actual position.Andall this could happen within the Union, then the urgent question is – what does the Union matter I raised this question verbally with an interested observer. He responded: ”The subvention perhaps  That may be why it matters.”It sounds convincing to say that the huge subsidy from the Treasury in London is what makes it all worthwhile. After all, that is what makes the province reasonably affluent. But you could just as easily argue that the other way – that the subsidy alongside relentless political concessions means that Irish nationalists within the province can enjoy all of their key demands, and the financial benefit too.One little-noticed, but intriguing, suggestion on the future that would have implications for this anomaly came from a recent writer on our  pages, Garvin Crawford. He suggested the world’s first community state in which people are able to designate themselves as Ulster British or Ulster Irish, and pay taxes and receive benefits accordingly.But, despite its logicality, the idea that those in Northern Ireland who opt for Irish citizenship would lose British benefits would surely provoke uproar amongst Irish nationalists globally.Union  will continue throughout the summer.Perhaps some of the coming contributors will address this question of what a secure Union means, and why it matters.• The essay above was written in August . I am surprised by parts of it, for example my reference to us one day needing a passport to get to Great Britain. There was no prospect of Brexit in , because David Cameron was new to power and had not promised his In-Out vote, but I think the idea was in my head because the Labour government had tried to introduce security measures for cross Irish Sea movements from which it retreated. Also, I had seen or reported on matters such as police sometimes in Belfast airports asking flight passengers from the mainland for a passport, rather than photo ID, and a Tory MP complaining about the same in Dublin in lack of observance of the Common Travel AreaThe sections on legacy above were brewing in  but are far worse now. Also, in  the Irish language push and Bill of Rights push were almost dormant but it was clear they were so central to republican goals that they would arise again.The expanding role of ‘enforcers’ has continued, as it was obvious in  it would.Similarly, the sections on Irish government partisanship, on the Irish presidencyand on contested terms such as Northern Ireland have become much more pronounced since Brexit, but I had forgotten until revisiting this essay the extent to which they were building regardless of the UK’s position in or out of the EU.The double standards in the Dublin establishment with regard to Sinn Fein having to be in power on one side of the border but not being allowed in the other have diminished in recent years as some Irish leaders seem to begin to prepare for striking a deal with them.• Ben Lowryis News Letter editor. Other articles by him below and information on how to subscribe to the paper:• Ben Lowry Nov : A poll that finds support for UK, DUP and ending protocol checks – not something you hear often• Ben Lowry Oct : Theof inflation will suit debtors and punish savers• Ben Lowry Oct : Tribute this week to a great News Letter columnist Ralph Bud Bossence• Ben Lowry Oct :Centenary church service should have celebrated Northern Ireland• Ben Lowry Oct : Lord Frost’s speech on NI reflected notably more robust UK tactics• Ben Lowry Oct : David Amess was a conscientious Tory MP who always seemed to be smiling• A message from the new editor Ben Lowry• Ben Lowry Oct : Echoes of , as Boris Johnson fails to proclaim his unionism in speech• Ben Lowry Oct : Unionism could make great headway lobbying in the United States• Ben Lowry Oct : A belated happy th birthday to ourselves at the News Letter!• A link to  columns by Ben Lowry——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make of you.With the coronavirus lockdowns having had a major impact on many of our advertisers — and consequently the revenue we receive — we are more reliant than ever on you taking out a digital subscription.Subscribe to newsletterand enjoy unlimited access to the best Northern Ireland and UK news and information online and on our app. With a digital subscription, you canthan  articles, see fewer ads, enjoy faster load times, and get access to exclusive newsletters and content. Visit https:www.newsletter subscriptionsto sign upOur journalism costs money and we rely on advertising, print and digital revenues to help to support them. By supporting us, we are able to support you in providing trusted, fact-checked content for this website.Ben Lowry, Editor

title: the shortage of drivers boosts the case for rail a tunnel to northern ireland
story: Patrick J Roche: Archbishop’s comments a moral indictment of unionism   TUV: Protocol dismantling the Union before our eyesNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionThe shortage of drivers boosts the case for rail a tunnel to Northern IrelandA letter from John Barstow:By LettersSaturday, th November , : am  "       "  More goods going by rail is a crucial ingredient of the ‘green revolution’The driver shortage issue has resulted in more retail chains including Tesco switching more from road to rail. This is more evidence that the rail tunnel to Northern Ireland is a concept whose time to come. More goods going by rail is a crucial ingredient of the ‘green revolution’.First of all it will be a win for the dynamics of the UK internal market with particular reference to perishable goods. Secondly goods of the Republic of Irelandcould be trucked to Belfast for direct transit by train to continental Europe.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Letter to the editorAll in all a win win. Plus more jobs for UK logistics sector through construction of a rail freight terminal in Belfast area.On the pesky issue of the Northern Ireland protocol. Irish Sea checks are as unnecessary as they are on the UK RoI border. I work in retail and can directly testy that any modern retail delivery operation is almost worthy of George Orwell’s  tracked from depot with latest remote technologies. Thus any notion of Great Britain supplies for Northern Ireland retail venues mysteriously “veering off track” is for the land of asteroids. However the construction of that Belfast tunnel will be to the benefit of UK, RoI and EU — and thus be leverage for Her Majesty’s Government in securing an outcome based upon simple pragmatism and common sense.John Barstow, Pulborough, West Sussex——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
